title: Sunak sacks Braverman to seize control and reset premiership
lead: An early reshuffle, foreign policy speech, potential good news on inflation and an opportunity to reset immigration policy in the space of one week could define Mr Sunak’s premiership
author: Arj Singh

body.text: Rishi Sunak’s patience with Suella Braverman has finally run out after months of increasingly controversial interventions, growing complaints from Conservative MPs and finally an act of insubordination.
The calls on the Prime Minister to sack his Home Secretary began over summer but picked up pace in the autumn.

Ms Braverman’s position began to look genuinely shaky just before Conservative Party conference in early October, when a number of LGBT+ Tory MPs complained formally to the Chief Whip after she claimed asylum seekers pretend to be gay to game the system and gain refugee status in the UK.

But last week proved to be the straw that broke the camel’s back, after Ms Braverman announced plans to stop charities giving homeless people tents and said some people were sleeping rough as a “lifestyle choice” – remarks that blindsided Downing Street.
The comments overshadowed the King’s Speech, one of Mr Sunak’s few remaining opportunities to reset his premiership by announcing a new legislative programme.

Meanwhile, Ms Braverman was facing accusations, including from Tory ministers, that she was fuelling the prospect of disorder on Armistice Day by describing pro-Palestinian protesters who planned to demonstrate as taking part in “hate marches”, a phrase no one in Cabinet has endorsed.

She faced accusations, again from Tory MPs, that she was emboldening the far-right, who eventually turned out in large numbers in counter-protests on Saturday and accounted for the larger proportion of arrests amid violent scenes.

Undeterred, Ms Braverman then doubled down. In an article for The Times, which No10 asked to be toned down, but wasn’t, she accused the police of showing bias in favour of pro-Palestinian and left-wing protesters compared to the firm hand they show to right-wing demonstrators.
Downing Street promptly launched an investigation into why Ms Braverman had refused to make edits to the article, and the act of insubordination appears to have done for her.
In sacking the most senior right-winger in his Cabinet, Mr Sunak will be aware that he risks triggering a war with that faction of MPs on his backbenches.
But he has perhaps made the calculation, as several Tories have told i, that Ms Braverman’s support among MPs is overstated.

In firing her before Wednesday’s Supreme Court verdict on the Rwanda deportation plan, he may have preempted Ms Braverman resigning and calling on the UK to quit the European Convention on Human Rights, if the judgement went against the Government.

Ms Braverman will now be hoping she attains martyr status on the right of the party that puts her in pole position for any future leadership race, likely after election defeat for the Tories next year.

By starting his reshuffle before that judgement, Mr Sunak appears determined to get on top of the crisis that has been gripping his party for months, with successive by-election defeats and rows over net zero as well as the conduct of Ms Braverman.
In fact, this week could define Mr Sunak’s premiership and give his party a fighting chance at the next election.

The Prime Minister will use a major foreign policy speech later on Monday to pledge to redouble efforts to pursue a two-state solution to the Middle East crisis. While this seems at the moment an impossible task, it will underline his attempts to be a serious world leader, in contrast to his two most immediate predecessors.

By taking Mrs Braverman out of the equation ahead of Wednesday’s Supreme Court ruling on the government’s Rwanda scheme, Mr Sunak has a chance to reset his beleaguered pledge to stop the small boats, whichever way the ruling goes, by adopting a less hardline position and potentially renegotiating the deal with Kigali.
Inflation figures published on Wednesday could – if forecasts are correct – show Mr Sunak is close to, or has already met, his pledge to halve the rate of prices by the end of this year.
This would mark the first of his five pledges met, and even though the other ones remain doubtful before the next election, it would be a significant success.
And finally, Mr Sunak could use this economic good news to give the go-ahead to tax cuts – potentially to inheritance tax and stamp duty – announced by Jeremy Hunt in his autumn statement next week.
Whatever happens this week, it will almost certainly set the course for Mr Sunak’s remaining time in office.

title: Former PM David Cameron stages remarkable comeback as he becomes new foreign secretary
lead: The former Prime Minister, who resigned after losing the Brexit referendum in 2016, has been granted a life peerage to allow him to sit in Cabinet
author: Joe Duggan

body.text: Former Prime Minister David Cameron has been confirmed as the new foreign secretary in a bombshell political comeback following a Cabinet reshuffle after Suella Braverman’s sacking.
Mr Cameron, who is no longer an MP, quit as prime minister after losing the Brexit referendum to Vote Leave in 2016.
But he was parachuted into the House Of Lords to allow him to take the Cabinet position, with James Cleverly confirmed as the new home secretary following Ms Braverman’s sacking.
The King confirmed the former prime minister had been granted a life peerage after being made Barony of the United Kingdom in a remarkable comeback to frontline politics.
Following his appointment, Mr Cameron said: “The Prime Minister has asked me to serve as his foreign secretary and I have gladly accepted.

“We are facing a daunting set of international challenges, including the war in Ukraine and the crisis in the Middle East. At this time of profound global change, it has rarely been more important for this country to stand by our allies, strengthen our partnerships and make sure our voice is heard.

“While I have been out of frontline politics for the last seven years, I hope that my experience – as Conservative leader for 11 years and prime minister for six – will assist me in helping the Prime Minister to meet these vital challenges.”
He admitted he had “disagreed with some individual decisions” made by Mr Sunak, but  praised him as a “strong and capable prime minister” who was “showing exemplary leadership at a difficult time”.

He added: “I want to help him to deliver the security and prosperity our country needs and be part of the strongest possible team that serves the United Kingdom and that can be presented to the country when the general election is held.”
After she was pushed out, Ms Braverman said “it has been the greatest privilege of my life to serve as home secretary”, adding: “I will have more to say in due course.”
Mr Cameron, who won a majority for the Tories in the 2015 election, was seen entering No 10 just minutes after Mr Cleverly this morning.
The Rt Hon @David_Cameron has been appointed Secretary of State for Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Affairs @FCDOGovUK pic.twitter.com/r9fL9dIgzs
Mr Cameron’s six years in office are best remembered for his decision to call a referendum on the UK leaving the European Union.
He became prime minister in 2010, leading a coalition government alongside the Liberal Democrats which oversaw a policy of steep austerity cuts to public services following the 2008 financial crash.
During the 2016 Brexit referendum Mr Cameron supported the Remain vote, but quit in the wake of Britain’s dramatic decision to leave the European Union by the narrowest of margins.
Related Article
The legal powers of police during protests, explained
In a tearful resignation speech outside No 10 on the morning of 24 June, 2016, he said: “The country requires fresh leadership to take it in this direction.

“I will do everything I can as prime minister to steady the ship over the coming weeks and months, but I don’t think it would be right for me to try to be the captain that steers our country to its next destination.”
In 2013, he became the first prime minister in more than 100 years to lose a foreign policy vote, after dozens of Tories joined Labour MPs to block his calls for military intervention in Syria.
Mr Cameron led the Conservative Party for 11 years, and became the youngest prime minister since Robert Banks Jenkinson, the 2nd Earl of Liverpool in 1812 after winning the 2010 election.

Since leaving No 10, he was at the centre of a major scandal after it emerged he privately lobbied ministers to attempt to try to secure access to an emergency coronavirus loan scheme for the failed firm Greensill Capital, where he took up a role in 2018.
Ms Braverman was sacked as home secretary as Mr Sunak took action following her unauthorised article criticising the way pro-Palestinian protests had been policed.
The Conservatives said Mr Sunak is carrying out a wider reshuffle which “strengthens his team in government to deliver long-term decisions for a brighter future”.

But sacking one of the leading figures on the Tory right could pose difficulties for the Prime Minister as he seeks to get his party united behind him and ready for a general election expected next year.
Mr Cleverly’s appointment as home secretary left a vacancy in his former role of foreign secretary, opening the way for Mr Cameron’s return.
How has David Cameron become foreign secretary?
David Cameron has become the 15th former prime minister to serve in a later government led by someone else after he was granted a life peerage.
It normally takes several weeks from the time a potential new peer is announced, by the Government or the House of Lords Appointments Commission, before their actual appointment.
Before anyone becomes a member, a title has to be agreed and legal documents called Letters Patent and Writ of Summons must be prepared.
Letters Patent are issued by the King and create a life peerage. Recipients become members when Letters Patent are sealed (marked to show royal approval).
They can then be written to at the House of Lords, using their new title of Lord or Baroness. They cannot sit in the chamber or vote until their introduction in the chamber.

Dr Catherine Haddon, from the Institute for Government, said she expected Mr Cameron would be inducted into the House of Lords by Wednesday, but he will be able to start his work as foreign secretary immediately.
She told i: “They will expedite it. So it will all happen quite rapidly. It’s quite normal for governments to appoint a minister and then appoint them to the House of Lords at the same time.
“He can still be a minister, he can go to the Foreign Office, he can attend Cabinet and all the rest of it.
“So he can do the job of government. He just can’t go and appear in the House of Lords until he has been, as it were, formally appointed and introduced there.

“He will be receiving phone calls from lots of dignitaries and so forth. All the ambassadors will be sending through their congratulations and he’ll be setting up phone calls with his key opposite numbers, all of our allies.
“And he will immediately be taking on whatever James Cleverly was due to be doing any visits, speeches or whatever – all that suddenly falls into his diary.”
How often have Cabinet ministers sat in the Lords?
The last foreign secretary to sit in the House of Lords was Lord Carrington in Margaret Thatcher’s government from 1979-82
Nicky Morgan was the last Cabinet minister to sit in the upper chamber after she was made culture secretary in 2019-2020.
Fourteen ex-premiers have previously come back in a different government role since the 18th century.
Sir Alec Douglas-Home, who served for just under a year as prime minister after taking office in October 1963, was later appointed foreign secretary by Edward Heath.
He held the role from 1970 until 1974 and is the last former PM to return to government under a different leader.

In earlier years, Arthur Balfour, who served as prime minister from 1902 until 1905, came back to government in the roles of the first lord of the admiralty in the wartime coalition, and then foreign secretary under David Lloyd George.
During the Second World War, Neville Chamberlain, who was succeeded by Sir Winston Churchill, went on to serve as lord president of the council in his Cabinet.

title: Rishi Sunak urged by senior Tories to back onshore renewable energy rather than oil and gas
lead: Polling has revealed strong support among Conservative voters for wind and solar farms
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Senior Tories have urged Rishi Sunak to back onshore renewable energy rather than off-shore oil and gas after a poll showed strong support for alternative power sources among Conservative voters.

A survey on behalf of the Conservative Environment Network (CEN) revealed that 82 per cent of people want to see more renewable energy in the UK, including 77 per cent of Tory voters at the 2019 election, and 81 per cent who plan to vote for the party next time.
In last week’s King’s Speech, the Prime Minister made a fresh push for new oil and gas licences in the North Sea.
The Government has insisted the expansion is essential to the UK’s energy security and will not affect its Net Zero targets.

But former Cabinet minister Sir Simon Clarke argued that the poll results showed there was a “silent majority” in favour of renewables and that backing onshore wind and solar should be at the heart of the Tories’ offer to the electorate.
The polling for CEN, by Public First, was conducted in 19 Conservative-held seats, including those where there are existing renewable energy developments.
Related Article
Green energy surges but fossil fuels still used for 80% of world power supply

The figures show that two-thirds of the public think the UK has been too slow to set up new onshore wind and solar farms, while 59 per cent of Tory voters would not oppose a wind farm in their own neighbourhood, even if it could be seen from their own window.

Voters prefer green energy development over the building of new houses in their local areas: 47 per cent would prefer both options, but when asked to choose, people are 27 per cent more likely to prefer a wind turbine or solar farm than local housing.
Some 69 per cent of 2019 Tory voters, who will continue to support Mr Sunak’s party at the next election, expected in 2024, believe the rollout of renewable energy in the UK has been too slow.

The 19 constituencies were selected for the survey as they were expected to show local opposition to such developments. But just 9 per cent of people in those seats had taken part in a campaign to oppose a renewable development in their area.
Sir Simon said the ongoing war in Ukraine and the crisis in the Middle East made the focus on energy security even more important.

He added: “Renewable energy will simultaneously protect British households from volatile fossil fuel markets and give us a much-needed economic boost. If we doubled our onshore wind capacity, we would generate £45bn of economic activity and help create 27,000 jobs.

“Our solar industry could be just as lucrative, potentially offering £70bn to our economy. As the cheapest forms of new energy, they will mitigate rising energy costs whilst weaning us off unreliable foreign imports.”

While there remained an “understandable nervousness” among Tory MPs about renewable energy projects, the polling showed how the politics on the issue had now changed and that they were an “electoral asset” to the party.

Sir Simon, a former levelling up secretary, added: “Just as I’ve argued strongly that we can’t win elections opposing new homes for the next generation, so too we can’t win by opposing cheap, clean renewable energy schemes. It’s the wrong approach economically and environmentally, as well as electorally.

“With the next election looming, we need to offer a positive vision for the future. Successive Conservative governments have enabled the development of the five biggest offshore wind farms in the world and the best decarbonisation record in the G7; we should point to these achievements with pride. We have to show the electorate not only we have delivered action on climate change, but we have a plan to finish the job. Let’s not be afraid to make renewables core to our offer.”
Public First surveyed 1,060 people between 16 and 24 August 2023.

title: Rishi Sunak pledges UK will ‘redouble’ efforts to secure two-state solution for Israel and Palestine
lead: The Prime Minister will use a speech in London on Monday to outline his vision for a ‘hard-headed’ foreign policy
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: Rishi Sunak says the UK will “redouble” its efforts to secure a two-state solution between Israel and Palestine amid the latest conflict in the region.
In his speech at the annual Lord Mayor’s Banquet in London’s Guildhall, the Prime Minister will set out his vision for UK foreign policy over the next year.

He is set to tell international dignitaries and business leaders that the UK will intensify its efforts to work towards a two-state solution – a proposed framework for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by establishing two states for each people.
He will say: “The UK wrote the original UN resolutions setting out a two-state solution. We’ve argued for it for decades. But now we must help make it a reality.
“So, to the UK’s friends across the region and to our communities in this country, I pledge to redouble British efforts to this end.”

The Prime Minister will also say that while the UK is pragmatic in its foreign policy approach, it is a time for “moral clarity” as he notes UK support for Kyiv in its struggle against Russia’s invasion and humanitarian support for civilians in Gaza amid the Israel-Hamas war.
“We’re hard-headed about what’s necessary for our interests and security. But Britain’s realism has always had values and this is a moment for moral clarity,” he will say.
He will say that Britain will never “lose patience” in backing Ukraine, calling Russian president Vladimir Putin’s invasion a “self-inflicted strategic calamity” that he “cannot win”.

Mr Sunak will use the speech to outline his vision for a “hard-headed” foreign policy approach that defends UK values from adversaries at a time for “moral clarity” as war rages in the Middle East and Ukraine.
The Prime Minister will speak of the UK’s desire to “shape the world” as he highlights his record on forging international partnerships on defence, trade and migration.
Calling 2023 “one of the most significant years” for UK foreign policy in recent times, he will highlight his record on forging international partnerships on defence, trade and migration.

This includes the signing of the Windsor Framework with the EU, the update of UK foreign and security policy and the announcement of plans for a new generation of nuclear-powered submarines under the Aukus partnership with the US and Australia.
The UK also struck migration deals with France, Italy and Albania, confirmed its accession to a major Indo-Pacific trade bloc, and hosted an international summit on artificial intelligence safety.

“These treaties and alliances speak to something deeper: our willingness to act, to shape the world, not be shaped by it, wherever there’s a challenge, wherever there’s a threat, wherever we can promote peace and security.”

title: Suella Braverman’s Rwanda plans face crucial court test on Wednesday – and could save her job
lead: The Supreme Court is to rule on the legality of plans to send migrants to Rwanda, but there are options open to the government if the judges find against it
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: The future of the Government’s flagship Rwanda policy faces a crucial test this week when the Supreme Court rules on its legality.
It was announced last Thursday that the Supreme Court would deliver its verdict on the legality of the Government’s plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda next week.
The decision comes after the Home Office challenged a previous decision after the Court of Appeal ruled in June that the policy was unlawful.

There are suggestions that the Government is expecting that the judgment will not go in its favour, which will mean exploring other options ranging from tweaking the policy to abandoning it altogether.

Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is under considerable pressure, however, to find a way to cut illegal migration to the UK, having made stopping small boats crossing the Channel one of his five key pledges to be achieved this year.

One avenue the Government could pursue if the policy is ruled unlawful is to strike a new deal with Rwanda, updating it from a memorandum of understanding with the UK to a treaty which would have to be ratified by MPs.

Another option is to pass a bill which designates Rwanda as a safe country, and insiders believe either of these moves could satisfy judges’ concerns and make the policy harder to challenge in the courts.
The Government could also expand the list of safe countries to which illegal migrants could be safely returned, with Georgia and India added to the list last week.
Related Article
Tory backlash over calls to quit ECHR as hardliners warned there is no majority for leaving

It’s widely believed that, if she remains in post, Ms Braverman will use a finding of unlawful to push for the UK to leave the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), a move backed by many Tory MPs on the right of the party.
The Home Secretary is said to pushing for the party to run a “Quit the ECHR” election campaign similar to Boris Johnson’s 2019 “Get Brexit Done” campaign, the Mail on Sunday reports.
But this stance could create further dividing lines between Ms Braverman and Mr Sunak, with the Prime Minister said to be in favour of tweaking the ECHR rather than abandoning it altogether.
The paper quotes a source close to the Prime Minister describing the ECHR as a “straitjacket” which “could be reformed to be less constrictive”.

Relations between the Prime Minister and his Home Secretary have been strained in recent weeks following her controversial comments describing rough sleeping as a “lifestyle choice” and pro-Palestine protesters as “hate marchers”.
The Supreme Court’s decision on the Rwanda policy could be a pivotal moment for her future in Cabinet.
If it is found to be unlawful, Mr Sunak may want to keep Ms Braverman in the Home Office as many MPs see her as best placed to lead on derogating from or abandoning the ECHR.

But, if Mr Sunak wants to take a more measure approach to appease the courts, he may choose to replace Ms Braverman with a more moderate figure in the next reshuffle, which is widely expected in the coming weeks.

title: Sunak urged by senior Tories to fire Braverman before Rwanda judgement or risk her becoming ‘unsackable’
lead: The Prime Minister is under intense pressure from his own MPs to take action against the Home Secretary
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Rishi Sunak should remove Suella Braverman as Home Secretary before the Supreme Court ruling on the government’s Rwanda policy or risk her becoming unsackable, senior Tories believe.
The Prime Minister is under intense pressure from his own MPs to take action against the minister after she openly defied him over Saturday’s mass pro-Palestinian protest.

Mr Sunak had been expected to wait until after this Wednesday’s court judgement on the Rwanda asylum scheme, which some insiders believe the government could lose, before taking action in a long-awaited Cabinet reshuffle.

But senior Tory MPs say that if the government wins in the Supreme Court, Mrs Braverman becomes unsackable, and even if it loses, the PM would be firing a minister over a policy that he himself has backed in full.

The row over Mrs Braverman’s conduct, including her Times article last week which has been blamed on stoking tensions among far-right activists and pro-Palestinian protesters, is also set to erupt at this Wednesday’s meeting of the backbench Tory 1922 committee, Informfully has been told.
A Tory former cabinet minister told i: “I believe Rishi has no choice but to sack her. This is an issue of authority.
“If she carries on then she will know that she can say what she likes without consequence and it also makes it easier for others in the Cabinet to speak their mind too.”

The Prime Minister should fire his Home Secretary “immediately”, on Monday or Tuesday this week, the ex-cabinet minister said, to avoid it being tied to Rwanda, adding: “It’s quite straightforward. She believes she can ignore the Prime Minister and that is an unacceptable position for him.”
The Home Secretary redoubled her rhetoric over Saturday’s pro-Palestinian protest, threatening “further action” against marchers.

She urged the police to take action against the “sick, inflammatory and clearly criminal” elements at the march in London, attended by more than 300,000 people, including anti-semitic chants and placards.

Downing Street is also considering toughening measures against the protests, Informfully understands, after a review of Saturday’s protests and counter-protests by far-right groups. These could include urging the police to use their full powers against protesters, or potentially a review of public order legislation.

The Home Secretary wrote on X, formerly Twitter: “Our brave police officers deserve the thanks of every decent citizen for their professionalism in the face of violence and aggression from protesters and counter-protesters in London yesterday”.
She said it was an “outrage” that multiple officers were “injured doing their duty” amid the protests after the Met confirmed that nine of its officers had been injured.

Referring to incidents at the pro-Palestinian march, Mrs Braverman added: “The sick, inflammatory and, in some cases, clearly criminal chants, placards and paraphernalia openly on display at the march mark a new low.
“Antisemitism and other forms of racism together with the valorising of terrorism on such a scale is deeply troubling.

“This can’t go on. Week by week, the streets of London are being polluted by hate, violence, and antisemitism. Members of the public are being mobbed and intimidated. Jewish people in particular feel threatened. Further action is necessary.”
Asked what “further action” by the government could mean, a No10 source said: “We should reflect on this weekend and make sure all powers were used as effectively as possible.
“There’s openness in government to go further if needed.”

Earlier, Defence Secretary Grant Shapps refused to state whether he believes Mrs Braverman will still be Home Secretary in a week’s time, becoming the latest Cabinet minister who has declined to give her his backing.

Asked on Sky News on Sunday whether he believed Ms Braverman’s sacking was imminent, Mr Shapps responded: “A week is a long time in politics, and I never make predictions about these things. It is entirely a matter for the Prime Minister.”
Mr Sunak is expected to receive a letter from an unknown number of Tory MPs urging the Prime Minister to keep the Home Secretary in post.
The letter has been organised by the Conservative MP John Hayes, a longstanding ally of Mrs Braverman, who could hand it in to Downing Street as early as Monday.
A senior Tory MP and supporter of the Home Secretary said: “The Prime Minister would like to get rid of her, because she’s a threat.”

Asked whether Mrs Braverman is deliberately trying to get sacked, the MP said: “It’s something that she seriously does believe in and she is frustrated by the fact that he won’t go as far as she would like him to. Beyond that, I think that she probably still has leadership ambitions.
“I think that she takes the view that if we lose the next election there will obviously be a very quick leadership contest. I think she may well be establishing her credentials.
“But I don’t think it’s necessarily a question of deliberately wanting to wind the PM up.”

title: Parents face £1,000 a year in ‘hidden’ childcare costs, figures show
lead: Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is under pressure to increase funding for nurseries in his Autumn Statement next week
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Jeremy Hunt is under pressure to boost childcare funding in the Autumn Statement after new figures revealed parents risk having to pay an extra £1,000 a year in hidden fees.

Some 85 per cent of councils currently have a shortfall between the Government’s funding of the 30 free hours of childcare a week provision and the fees charged by nurseries, analysis of official figures by the Liberal Democrats has shown.
On average, parents of three to four-year-olds, who are entitled to 30 free hours a week, risk paying £19.50 a week to fund the gap, or £1,014 a year.

Some councils are experiencing much bigger shortfalls in funding, including North Somerset, where parents face paying an extra £70.80 a week for every child in nursery, followed by Brent, north London, at £69.90 a week and Richmond-upon-Thames, south-west London, at £63 a week.
Related Article
Sunak's childcare plan could shut thousands of nurseries. Here's what he should do instead
Parents in nine local authorities across the country could be forced to find £45 or more per child per week to fund the deficit, according to the analysis of Department for Education figures.
The figures do not reveal whether the costs are passed on to parents or whether the local authorities have to fund the shortfall. But either way, the gap means an extra burden for taxpayers.

Liberal Democrat education spokesperson Munira Wilson urged the Chancellor to take action in his autumn statement on 22 November. She added: “If the Government wants to boost the economy then it must tackle the gaping hole in childcare costs.
“The Autumn Statement next week must address this or else families and ultimately the economy will continue to suffer.

“The UK already has some of the highest childcare costs in the world. Parents up and down the country are struggling to afford their nursery fees, while for others the crippling costs of childcare mean they simply can’t afford to return to work.
“There is a huge crisis looming with both nurseries and local councils warning of a collapse if the Government doesn’t come forward with proper funding.”
Ministers have been repeatedly warned that funding for “free” childcare provision does not meet the cost to nurseries, with some settings forced to close due to the shortfall.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies recently estimated that “core resources per hour for 3- and 4-year-olds in 2024–25 will be 11 per cent below their level in 2012-13 once providers’ costs are taken into account”.

title: Suella Braverman threatens ‘further action’ over Gaza protests and claims London ‘polluted by hate’
lead: The Home Secretary issues the warning despite opponents blaming her comments for inciting a far-right counter-demonstration
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: Suella Braverman has threatened “further action” against pro-Palestine protesters following a march in London.

More than 300,000 people calling for a ceasefire in the conflict between Israel and Gaza marched through the city centre on Saturday, while more than 120 counter-protesters were arrested in and around Westminster.
Footage shared online showed the counter-protesters, many of whom were from far-right groups, clashing with police near the Cenotaph.
The Met Police have also launched numerous calls for information into potential hate crimes following reports of antisemitic chants and signs at the pro-Palestine march.
Related Article
Jewish children told to hide uniforms as UK schools strengthen security

In a statement, Ms Braverman said: “Our brave police officers deserve the thanks of every decent citizen for their professionalism in the face of violence and aggression from protesters and counter-protesters in London yesterday”.
The Home Secretary added that it was an “outrage” that multiple officers were “injured doing their duty” amid the protests after the Met confirmed that nine of its officers had been injured.

She went on to directly refer to incidents at the pro-Palestine march, adding: “The sick, inflammatory and, in some cases, clearly criminal chants, placards and paraphernalia openly on display at the march mark a new low.
“Antisemitism and other forms of racism together with the valorising of terrorism on such a scale is deeply troubling.

“This can’t go on. Week by week, the streets of London are being polluted by hate, violence, and antisemitism. Members of the public are being mobbed and intimidated. Jewish people in particular feel threatened. Further action is necessary.”
Her statement did not specifically single out the violent far-right protests by name, aside from the reference to both “protesters and counter-protesters”.

Opponents including Mayor of London Sadiq Khan, Scotland’s first minister Humza Yousaf and Labour’s shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper have attempted to link the counter-protests – which police said on Saturday was the source of most violent altercations – to the Home Secretary’s past rhetoric about pro-Palestinian protests, which she refers to as “hate marches”.

The Home Secretary was heavily criticised ahead of the protest for claiming in an article for The Times that the marches were “an assertion of primacy by certain groups – particularly Islamists – of the kind we are more used to seeing in Northern Ireland”.

She also claimed that “some of Saturday’s march group organisers have links to terrorist groups, including Hamas” and suggested there is “a perception that senior police officers play favourites when it comes to protesters”.
No 10 has stated it was “looking into what happened” in relation to the article, after confirming that its contents were “not agreed” by Downing Street.
Numerous Cabinet ministers have already distanced themselves from her comments, with Chancellor Jeremy Hunt stating that “the words that she used are not words that I myself would have used”.
But some senior Tory MPs are urging Mr Sunak to sack Ms Braverman, saying they back her “common sense” approach to policing.
A group of senior Tory MPs are allegedly making a direct appeal to Rishi Sunak not to sack Ms Braverman because they back her “common sense” approach to policing.
Members of the Common Sense Group are writing to Mr Sunak and urging him to resist pressure to remove the embattled Home Secretary, according to the Daily Telegraph.
John Hayes, the chairman of the group, has been contacted by Informfully for comment.

title: Have Arsenal stumbled upon a solution to their No 9 problem?
lead: Gabriel Jesus’ injury troubles have led to a lot of experimentation
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: This is an extract of The Score. Click the sign-up box below to receive the newsletter every Monday morning this season for Daniel Storey’s verdict on all 20 Premier League clubs

I think we have to conclude that Gabriel Jesus cannot be relied upon to start more than 25 league games a season. The striker is wanted by the Brazilian football federation this week, who it seems aren’t convinced by Arsenal’s prognosis, but Mikel Arteta has said that the latest injury is a huge worry and Jesus is not expected to play until December. He has played 363 minutes in the Premier league this season.

As alternatives, Arteta has started Eddie Nketiah as the central striker and seen him score a hat-trick. He has started Kai Havertz there in the Community Shield and seen him do about as much as he has in central midfield. He started Leandro Trossard as a false nine and as a more conventional centre forward.

Nketiah probably wouldn’t agree, but you wonder whether Trossard might just be the answer moving forward. His creativity, tendency to drift left (and allow Gabriel Martinelli to move centrally) and set-piece delivery are all useful to Arsenal. Trossard, naturally a left winger, is able to drag defenders out of position that could be crucial against a deep-lying defence. Against Burnley, he was able to repeatedly find space around the penalty area and scored when finding space inside it.
Related Article
Newcastle's winner exposed VAR's fatal flaws - football should look to cricket for an answer

Interestingly, Arteta spoke last season after a win at Leicester about how the switching of positions with Martinelli can increase Arsenal’s creativity: “He [Trossard] is so good in the small spaces. He’s got that creativity to open people up and I’m really happy with him. We have the option to play Leo as the No 9 and we have the option to play Gabi as the No 9 and Leo on the left.”

The theory is this: if Nketiah plays and is presented with chances, that system works fine. But if Nketiah is starved of the ball, Arsenal can become a little formulaic and opponents can double up on Martinelli and Bukayo Saka, particularly if Havertz isn’t a threat from midfield. In those scenarios, they would be better having the flexible forward.

title: The Score: Our chief football writer’s verdict on all 20 Premier League teams after Gameweek 12
lead: Injuries threaten Spurs and Newcastle’s fortunes, Harry Maguire’s renaissance and Arsenal’s striker dilemma
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Click the sign-up box below to receive The Score newsletter every Monday morning this season
This is threatening to be the most chaotic season in a long time. Not only has the VAR circus and a spate of muscle injuries made things weird, we also have five teams separated by two points.
Aston Villa, who lost at Nottingham Forest last week, are now two points behind the Manchester City team we thought might run away with the league and nothing makes sense anymore.

At the bottom, none of the promoted clubs won again, so Bournemouth were the big winners after beating a laboured Newcastle team. The Cherries’ former manager is having fun too: Gary O’Neil’s Wolves scored two injury-time goals to beat Tottenham.
This weekend’s results
Saturday
Sunday
If there’s one team sinking into trouble as we break for internationals, might it be Fulham? They have won twice since the opening day and look chronically short of goals…
Read my analysis on every team below (listed in table order).
Man City

While Erling Haaland was obviously ecstatic at winning the Gerd Muller Trophy at the Ballon d’Or as Europe’s highest scoring player, there were shots of the player looking a bit sultry after the ceremony. And you can understand why: he had just been victim to football’s most high-profile robbery since Bobby Moore was accused of stealing a £625 diamond and emerald bracelet at the 1970 World Cup.

The Norwegian had plundered 52 goals in 53 games, a record-crushing 36 in the Premier League and 12 in the Champions League while winning the Treble, all in his debut season aged only 22. Lionel Messi had won the World Cup, granted, and a few trophies in France, but had he not been Lionel Messi there would be no question. Haaland would have been crowned No 1, not little-remembered second place.
Related Article
Haaland’s genius cancelled out by late Palmer penalty as Chelsea hold Man City in thriller

He may never win a Treble again, will probably never win a World Cup or European Championship with Norway, but more goal-scoring records will tumble. Twenty goals in 21 games this season, his two against Chelsea moving him to 49 goals in 47 Premier League games. After being quicker to 10, 20, 30 and 40 Premier League goals than any other striker, if he scores once in the next 17 games he will beat Andy Cole’s record of half-a-century of top-flight goals in 65 games, besting the very best to have played in England, including Alan Shearer and Ruud van Nistelrooy.
And there is so much more to him than merely goals. For Haaland and City’s first, it was clever No 9 play to win the penalty. Because — let’s be honest — it was clearly won.

Haaland and Marc Cucurella had as much of each other’s shirts before the City striker burst in front of the Chelsea defender before going down. It’s hard to believe Cucurella would even have the strength to wrestle Haaland to the floor if he tried. By Sam Cunningham.
Liverpool

This summer, Mohamed Salah was the subject of some massive interest from Saudi Arabia and an eye-watering offer. When that offer landed, I believed Liverpool should take it because it was the area of the pitch in which they had the most cover, because of Salah’s age and because it was a huge amount of money. The other factor was that I couldn’t see Liverpool winning the title and they weren’t in the Champions League, so this made sense as a transition season while they bedded in their new midfielders.

Yeah, I might have got that badly wrong (no, not “as usual”). It is certainly true the offer was massive, but then that might still be on the table next year just so long as Saudi Arabia haven’t given up on the need to buy expensive footballers now they have won the rights to host the World Cup.

More importantly, Liverpool may yet be in a title challenge because this season is becoming impossible to work out. Just when you think you have seen a team’s strengths, they flip over to show you the weakness. Liverpool certainly have their own, but the home form is relentless and that might just be enough if Manchester City stutter.

Salah is flying. On Sunday he reached 200 goals in English football. After failing to assist or score in his previous three club games, the brace against Brentford made it 14 goals and assists in the league alone. The only person with more than that is Erl… OK, obviously you know who it is.
Arsenal

We have to conclude that Gabriel Jesus cannot be relied upon to start more than 25 league games a season. The striker is wanted by the Brazilian football federation this week, who it seems aren’t convinced by Arsenal’s prognosis, but Mikel Arteta has said that the latest injury is a huge worry and Jesus is not expected to play until December. He has played 363 minutes in the Premier league this season.

As alternatives, Arteta has started Eddie Nketiah as the central striker and seen him score a hattrick. He has started Kai Havertz there in the Community Shield and seen him do about as much as he has in central midfield. He started Leandro Trossard as both a false nine and a more conventional centre forward.
Related Article
Arsenal have one major advantage over Spurs that makes them true title contenders

Nketiah probably wouldn’t agree, but you wonder whether Trossard might just be the answer moving forward. His creativity, tendency to drift left (and allow Gabriel Martinelli to move centrally) and set-piece delivery are all useful to Arsenal. Trossard, naturally a left winger, is able to drag defenders out of position that could be crucial against a deep-lying defence. Against Burnley, he was able to repeatedly find space around the penalty area and scored when finding space inside it.
Interestingly, Arteta spoke last season after a win at Leicester about how the switching of positions with Martinelli can increase Arsenal’s creativity:

“He [Trossard] is so good in the small spaces. He’s got that creativity to open people up and I’m really happy with him. We have the option to play Leo as the No 9 and we have the option to play Gabi as the No 9 and Leo on the left.”

The theory is this: if Nketiah plays and is presented with chances, that system works fine. But if Nketiah is starved of the ball, Arsenal can become a little formulaic and opponents can double up on Martinelli and Bukayo Saka, particularly if Havertz isn’t a threat from midfield. In those scenarios, you’d be better having the flexible forward.
Tottenham

Ah well, it was fun while it lasted. All season, sensible Tottenham supporters have been telling everybody around them who would listen that this squad might be too thin to sustain a top-four push, let alone a title challenge. But even those emphatic realists didn’t expect all of those problems to afflict Tottenham in the space of 90 minutes.

James Maddison will be out for a while, after his ankle injury is worse than Tottenham medics first feared. Cristian Romero is out for another two matches. Micky van de Ven has a hamstring injury that left him barely able to walk from the pitch. They were already dealing with the haunting fear caused by the departure of Pape Matar Sarr and Yves Bissouma to the Africa Cup of Nations in January and Son Heung-min to the Asian Cup at the same time.
Related Article
Postecoglou's mad tactics have put the fun back into Spurs - no wonder fans applaud a defeat

Ange Postecoglou spoke about “running out of steam” at Molineux on Saturday, and he’s probably right. But this was also an indication of the problem faced by every manager with a defined playing style that demands complete buy-in from the players. When you then bring in fringe players who haven’t played much competitive action in your system, they can struggle to replicate it.

And so to the last 10 minutes. Tottenham had already sat deeper than Postecoglou would like, trying to hold onto a lead rather than playing their own way regardless of the scoreline (as we saw so emphatically on Monday night). The manager said as much: “We started well but we could have been a little bit more positive, a little bit more aggressive, particularly with the ball.”

Instead, the changes to the team, particularly in defence, made those players implement risk-averse football which, counterintuitively, becomes more risky when it goes against the manager’s own preferred style. Suddenly you’ve got Eric Dier launching the ball out for throw-ins rather than trying to keep possession and Wolves ramping up pressure that the makeshift defence was then unable to repel.

This doesn’t all have to be the end, obviously. The next two fixtures – Aston Villa and Manchester City – are unhelpfully tricky, given Romero and Van de Ven will both likely be missing for both. But more important is that those who were getting carried away – inside and outside Tottenham’s support – temper their expectations a touch. Qualifying for the Champions League was always the high-end achievement of this first Spurs season under a new regime. If Maddison and Van de Ven are out for a significant period of time, January is going to make that very difficult indeed.
Aston Villa

Another week and another home win, because that is all Aston Villa apparently do at Villa Park now. This makes it 13 home league wins on the spin. Even more ridiculous is that Unai Emery’s team have now scored three or more goals in each of their last six home games in the Premier League.
Related Article
'Detail is key': Five ways Emery has transformed Aston Villa after the dark days of Gerrard

There were two noticeable features of the win over Fulham that deserve mention. The first is simple: Emery chose not to make a high number of changes, a different strategy to other managers around him. Matty Cash, Douglas Luiz and Pau Torres were the players to return. Villa took a commanding early lead and then played lower-energy football to preserve their reserves. That is an effective way to get through post-European assignments, particularly at home. Brighton, take note.

It was one of those returnees who impressed most. Villa paid £33m for Pau Torres in the summer, seen by some as a risky signing given the question marks over whether he would suit the Premier League and Villa’s multiple options in the position. Then Tyrone Mings got a serious injury and Torres stepped up to be the leader of the defence.

Torres is such a useful player for Emery’s system because he is capable of conducting the speed of play in possession. Often he plays the short, sideways passing we expect from so many teams. But his passing range, switching up to either arrow a long ball out to a wide forward or through the lines to an advanced midfielder, just makes Villa tick. He is a supreme passer of the ball and he’s doing it from centre-back. That is what Emery craves most.
Man Utd

Something extraordinary happened this week. At Wembley Stadium, Gareth Southgate announced his England squad for two forthcoming European Championship qualifiers. He included Harry Maguire and… there wasn’t a widespread guffawing. Wonders will never cease.

After all of the setbacks – the decline in club form, the ostracism from the first team, the mockery of supposed friends and foes because it really is funny to victimise a player until he reveals his mental struggle and then the same people tweet #BeKind – Maguire has, somehow, come back as strong.

Erik ten Hag tried to avoid it for as long as possible, but Maguire is back in the team and back performing. He was arguably United’s best player against Sheffield United, was definitely their best player against Fulham and the highest performer again against Luton on Saturday. Between all that, he scored the winner against FC Copenhagen and was again arguably Man of the Match.

This is no joke. It is not easy to come into any team having been left out in the cold – least of all when that team is struggling in front of a new goalkeeper and with injuries mounting up. Maguire’s start against Brentford on October 7 was his seventh in the league since August 2022. Add in the pressure upon him given the derision and mockery he had previously faced, and you have a bloke who deserves enormous respect for his strength of character.
Newcastle

The energy is running out and the impact of last season’s impressive Champions League qualification is becoming increasingly apparent. The danger is that Newcastle lose out both ways. They are bottom of their Champions League group and are favourites to stay there ahead of a trip to Paris that could eliminate them from the knockout stages.
Related Article
Newcastle may be forced to rip up January transfer strategy as injury crisis bites

Eddie Howe’s team have played four games on the weekends after their Champions League fixtures and have dropped points in three of them. At Wolves, they were lucky to escape with a point. At West Ham the same, albeit with their opponents looking equally blunted by midweek commitments. At Bournemouth on Saturday, Newcastle lost 2-0 and Nick Pope was their best player.

It isn’t just the fatigue in those who do play. The rapid increase in midweek matches and subsequent lack of recovery time has clearly played a role in Newcastle’s injury crisis. They were without nine players at Bournemouth, Miguel Almiron went off injured and they have no fit strikers. It’s a point we’ve raised before, but having all those full-backs and relying upon Callum Wilson’s fitness over a 50-game season was simply too risky.

“We couldn’t be where we needed to be for it,” said Eddie Howe after the game. “In and out of possession we were unrecognisable. They’re such honest players and they’ve given me so much that I’m absolutely clear I have to support them.”

Howe is clearly right, if a little resigned. You can’t simply magic energy back into your squad by repeatedly listening to Jake Humphrey’s “High Performance Podcast”. The only answer is for Newcastle to cope or, as is more likely, fall into the Europa League or worse and focus on the Premier League.

More interesting is how this season is playing out amongst an element of the club’s supporters. Changes to the club’s ticketing system means that there are newer faces in the away end this year, and Newcastle have only won one of their six away league games. At full-time on Saturday evening, Kieran Trippier argued with one supporter who was clearly giving the team grief. That simply wouldn’t have happened last season because everybody was supporting everybody else. It’s worth keeping an eye on any foolish entitlement growing.
Brighton

Like Newcastle one place above them, Brighton have an injury crisis likely caused by the addition of midweek European games into their usual schedule. For Sunday’s visit of Sheffield United, the list of absentees was as follows: Lewis Dunk, Pervis Estupinan, Tariq Lamptey, Solly March, James Milner, Danny Welbeck, Julio Enciso. To which we can add Evan Ferguson, omitted from the matchday squad at late notice after picking up an injury. Brighton’s squad is thinner than Newcastle’s, albeit the versatility of certain players helps to hide it.
Related Article
'I don't like 80% of English referees': Brighton's De Zerbi lashes out after Sheff Utd draw

Even so, Roberto De Zerbi still got it wrong against Sheffield United. Leaving Kaoru Mitoma on the bench was vaguely understandable, but it left a front three of Facundo Buonanotte (18), Simon Adingra and Ansu Fati (both 21 and in their first seasons in England). If that sounds like an attacking unit that might be a little raw, so it proved.

A manager cannot legislate for silly mistakes such as Mahmoud Dahoud getting himself sent off for a brainless tackle. But the question is how Brighton’s stability is being affected by the constant changes in team selection that De Zerbi feels that he needs to make. There were another six changes from Thursday to Sunday, but even that doesn’t demonstrate the full change: Pascal Gross to right-back, a new goalkeeper, a new central defender, a new left-back, two new midfielders and that raw front three.

You see the impact of those changes most in defence. Brighton have played 12 league games this season and are still yet to keep a clean sheet. They were fortunate to avoid defeat against a Sheffield United side that is yet to pick up an away point this season. De Zerbi’s team have also not won a Premier League match since 24 September.
West Ham
Related Article
Arsenal should start wondering why they didn’t spend £30m on James Ward-Prowse

West Ham signing James Ward-Prowse was the most obvious transfer of the Premier League summer. West Ham had lost an influential central midfielder and so needed a new one with experience. West Ham had two big central defenders and a towering central midfielder. David Moyes enthuses about the importance of a set-piece threat.

Ward-Prowse had actually seemed more of a threat from open play in the early season, but worry no longer. When West Ham began to win corner after corner, and wide free-kick after wide-free-kick, you sensed what was coming. It took West Ham to go 2-1 down, but then came the peppering.

Ward-Prowse now has five league assists this season. West Ham have scored seven headed goals and had 40 headed shots, both of which place them No 1 in the division. Some things just make sense, and Ward-Prowse hanging crosses to the back post or under the goalkeeper’s eyes is one of them.
Chelsea
Related Article
Haaland’s genius cancelled out by late Palmer penalty as Chelsea hold Man City in thriller

Whether Cole Palmer left Manchester City purely because he wasn’t guaranteed game time or because his sale made sense from a FFP perspective (is there any more romantic phrase in football than “pure profit”?), he has taken to life at Chelsea just fine. Stamford Bridge has been a Bermuda Triangle for a series of younger signings over the last two years, but Palmer is now the first name on the Chelsea teamsheet.

You can argue that being given penalty duties is an easy way to inflate your statistics, and that would make you a fool. Palmer is 21 years old and in Chelsea’s last five matches he has been asked to take one penalty against Arsenal, one against Tottenham and another against his old club. He’s scored all three beautifully.

There is bags of talent on the ball and work off it, but more than anything else managers look for leadership qualities in young players, for their ability to produce their best work under intense pressure. That sums up Palmer perfectly. Chelsea have landed one here.
Brentford
This isn’t just about Thomas Frank, but this is the only obvious place to make this wider point. After the game, Frank railed against a VAR decision.

“My look is that first and foremost, on the pitch it was a clear foul and a yellow card. But in the old days, and I’m not that old but let’s say five years ago, it was never a red. A yellow probably on the pitch, but these days with the VAR and the way they are being reffed, then I think it’s a red.

“If you look at the slow motion footage that you use, then it’s clear studs on leg and he’s definitely going over the ball with too much force, Endo on Christian. And then you can look at the four bloody marks on his leg! With that in mind, I just want consistency.”

You could make the argument, I guess. It looked like both players were going in and neither used two feet, but you could potentially make a case for it – it was a subjective decision and the call was that it didn’t quite merit a red card. But Brentford were also 2-0 down at that point.

VAR is a circus at the moment. But part of the reason for that is because VAR dominates every post-match discussion in studios and in every post-match press conference. It creates a scandal where one need not exist.

And it’s exhausting. If what you/we/everyone wants is more correct decisions and a better culture around refereeing decisions, at some point we’re all going to have to grow up a bit. We’ve got journalists saying “hey I’m just asking questions here” about corruption. We’ve got managers like Roberto De Zerbi saying he “dislikes 80 per cent of English referees”. We’ve got constant mania around every call. How is any of this going to help?
Wolves

All hail the Gary O’Neil midtable party. Supporters would be more than happy to admit that there have been doubts along the way (and the defeat to Sheffield United was an unfortunate misstep), but Wolves are now scampering away from danger at a rate of knots.

Since they lost to Liverpool in mid-September, their fourth defeat in five league games to open the season, Wolves have taken 12 points from seven matches and lost only once. They are unbeaten in four at Molineux, which sounds far more impressive when you learn that their four opponents were Manchester City, Tottenham, Aston Villa and Tottenham.
Related Article
'Big dog behaviour': Inside Gary O'Neil's Wolves start and the moment that changed everything

Of all the possible indicators of a squad enjoying life under a manager, two jump out at Wolves. The first is the improvement in players whose form dipped badly last season (or barely even got off the ground). Jose Sa seems more confident. Rayan Ait-Nouri is useful again. Matheus Cunha looks more like the player they thought they were getting. Pablo Sarabia woke up in style on Saturday.

Secondly, look at the fight within this Wolves team. Liverpool and Arsenal are the only two Premier League teams (by the end of Saturday’s action) to have scored more goals after the 80th minute than O’Neil’s this season. They won at Everton in the 87th minute. They came down from a goal and a man down to draw at Luton. They scored an 88th-minute winner at Bournemouth. They scored twice in stoppage time against Tottenham, believing that they could win the game immediately after getting back into it.

Those goals alone account for more than half of Wolves’ points so far this campaign. Without them, they and O’Neil would be in trouble. With them comes proof of a decent manager who has found a group of willing workers and worries of relegation that now look utterly wasted.
Crystal Palace

Those leaving Selhurst Park on Saturday afternoon more than a little grumpy and underwhelmed (and Roy Hodgson was amongst them) has their minds full of an unpleasant question that may have a lingering impact: where has Crystal Palace’s home form gone?

The inability to win at home is, ultimately, what did for Patrick Vieira. He failed to win each of his last seven home league games as Palace scored only twice. That run did include four draws against decent opposition – Manchester United, Newcastle, Brighton, Liverpool – but the mood at Selhurst became a little too apathetic.

Hodgson changed all that. He won his first home game 2-1 against Leicester and then took eight points from his next four to close out the season. When Palace promptly beat Wolves 3-2 in early September to overshadow a narrow home defeat to Arsenal on the opening weekend, all seemed well. That was 14 points from seven home league games in total – you don’t get much better than that at bottom-half clubs.

Since then, that home form has declined badly. Palace have drawn against Fulham and Nottingham Forest, lost to Tottenham and then conceded three times at home to Everton on Saturday. They suddenly seem incapable of displaying any resolve against pressure. Tyrick Mitchell is off form; so too is Marc Guehi.

Hodgson admitted after the game that the Selhurst form was “very concerning” and he’s right. Palace are thankful that they have won away at Manchester United and Burnley in two of their last three away games otherwise they would be down in trouble. Luton and Bournemouth come immediately after the international break. This is not the time for things to fall apart.
Everton

Things we expected Sean Dyche to do at Everton: 1) Make them harder to beat away from home; 2) Make them defensively miserly at home; 3) Create a set-piece threat; 4) Get them to cross the ball repeatedly into the box.

In the early days, barely any of these were present. But gradually, Dyche is turning Everton into exactly what he wanted, a high-end version of his Burnley team but with extra attacking threat and midfield guile. There is fight in this team, demonstrated by twice being pegged back and twice pushing back to retake the lead.
Related Article
Everton's takeover takes crucial next step in latest sign club's fortunes are changing

There is also an unrivalled ability to score early goals. In their last three matches in all competitions alone, Everton have scored in the first, seventh and 13 minutes. They have scored more goals in the first 15 minutes of Premier League games than anyone else and also a higher proportion. Thirty-six per cent of Everton’s goals have come in the 15th minute or earlier. Is this evidence that opposition managers presume that a Dyche team will aim to work its way into a match and are being tricked?

Whatever the reason, it’s working for Dyche. Everton have taken 10 points from their last five league games and that includes the customary defeat at Anfield. The threat of a points deduction is the same, but its impact is being mitigated. And now Everton have won consecutive away league games for the first time since May 2021.

As for those expectations of Dyche, he’s showing off new tricks too. Everton have scored three or more goals in three of their last eight away league games. Before that, they hadn’t scored three or more in a Premier League away game in 44 attempts, a run stretching back to February 2021.
Nottingham Forest

Same old, same old. The win over Aston Villa last week was earned via a defensive masterclass, with Forest repelling set pieces and Villa pressure before capitalising on the counter attack. Here was the opposite: Forest conceded plenty of set pieces and then proved themselves incapable of holding on.

Forest’s ability to lose games having held a lead is unmatched in the Premier League. They have done so seven times since the start of last season, more than any other team. Part of the issue is what happens once Taiwo Awoniyi is substituted. The centre forward is coming back from injury and so was never likely to play 90 minutes, but that’s par for the course. Awoniyi has never played 90 minutes for Forest in any competition and has only passed 80 minutes three times.

Awoniyi is so good at holding up the ball that, when he leaves the pitch, Forest lose an outlet (sorry Chris Wood, this isn’t your thing at all). That allows the opposition to push further up the pitch and squeeze Forest’s defenders and midfielders, thus causing them to panic and either give the ball away or put it out of play.

That left the course of the game to be decided by the result of those set pieces. Forest left Jarrod Bowen free from four yards out and then Tomas Soucek, the biggest player on the pitch, free at the back post to score the winner. These are the sort of things that make defeat more frustrating and entirely merited.
Fulham
Related Article
The Fulham fans leading the fightback against football's exorbitant ticket prices

It’s difficult to criticise any team for losing at Villa Park these days, but Fulham potentially do have a problem. The signing of a new contract by Marco Silva was heralded as a sign of investment in their future, but Silva is struggling to stem the tide at the moment. Fulham have won two league matches since the opening day of the season: Luton Town at home, Sheffield United at home.

Before the game, a couple of Fulham’s players were asked whether the loss of Aleksandar Mitrovic was the deciding factor and all of them denied that to be the case. And they’re right: of course Fulham are missing Mitrovic’s presence (they have scored more than once in two league games this season), but they have also failed to keep a clean sheet in six games and are asking – and expecting – Joao Palhinha to do everything. I can promise you he will get sick of that with Bayern Munich sniffing.

To that we must add the discontentment of home supporters, who campaigned last week about the greed of their club in their ticket pricing system, and the lingering resentment over allowing Mitrovic to leave without having an adequate replacement lined up. As we head into the international break, the best Fulham fans can hope for is a slightly wasted season.
Bournemouth

Dominic Solanke is going through what we might call the Ollie Watkins Centre Forward Revival. The impact might not be as pronounced, but it might just make Bournemouth’s season worthwhile and it certainly helped Andoni Iraola beat Newcastle to cement his own position.

Last season, Solanke scored six goals in 33 Premier League matches. Despite Bournemouth struggling at the start of this season, Solanke has six goals in 12 matches. And that’s not just down to the quality of his finishing. In 2022-23, Solanke managed a total 9.1 xG in the league – he’s already up to 5.4 this season.

As with Watkins, this is all about being refined into a centre forward rather than an all-action one. Playing further up the pitch means that he is playing fewer passes and those passes are much shorter in length (last season he would drop deep and play crossfield balls). Solanke has provided one assist this season (seven last year) and that’s because he’s creating fewer chances.

And so to the statistics that really matter. Solanke is taking more shots than last year and those shots are, on average, significantly closer to goal – inevitably his shooting efficiency goes up. And although he’s having fewer touches of the ball than last season, he’s having a greater number in the opposition penalty area.
Luton Town

Rob Edwards is right that Luton have come a long way in three months. That he, his players and the away supporters were deeply disappointed to leave Old Trafford having lost by a single goal is enough evidence of that. Edwards’ claim that Luton had “almost as much of the ball” was only true for the second half, but they certainly didn’t lie down and had six (admittedly low-danger) shots.
Related Article
Luton fans shamed their club with Liverpool tragedy chants and should be punished

Edwards’ issue is not that his team is poor in attack and defence, at least compared with our preseason expectations. It is that Luton are losing tight matches through their inability to keep clean sheets. They have allowed an xG of at least 1 in all but one game this season (the 1-1 home draw against Wolves, who had 10 men for an hour). They have conceded a goal in every league game too.

The lack of a clean sheet need not be a problem. Brighton have also not kept one, but then they are scoring at a rate of 2.1 goals per game. Luton’s problem is that they are not getting full value for the positives within their performances because they are being punished for ceding one too many good chances.

If you have conceded one goal or fewer in six matches this season, one fewer than Tottenham and Newcastle, you should be higher up the league. But the attack isn’t quite bailing out the defence and the defence isn’t quite bailing out the attack. That might just become the story of the season.
Burnley

There are certain non-negotiables for every promoted team, and one of them is defending crosses and set-pieces into the box. It is typically an area of strength, purely because the Championship tends to breed defenders who are capable of headed clearances – there are typically more long balls and more crosses into the box. After promotion, you cede a little more possession and territory and therefore expect an onslaught. If you can be beaten by terrific movement, you must guard against being undone by the basics.

Burnley aren’t even doing that. They actually defended pretty well in front of their own penalty area on Saturday, but repeatedly conceded chances – and goals – from wide areas. For the first, a cross comes from wide and Burnley lose the first header in their penalty area and leave Leandro Trossard free for the second. The third goal comes from a corner, with a header hitting the crossbar before Oleksandr Zinchenko’s wonderful finish.

The second goal is the most alarming. When Trossard’s corner is delivered, William Saliba is beyond the back post. Not only is he allowed to run beyond Zeki Amdouni (who ends up berating his teammates, for some reason), but that run is not spotted by anyone else. Saliba ends up standing in front of goalkeeper James Trafford, on his own a yard away from goal. The corner is delivered perfectly and Trafford is helpless.

This isn’t good enough. An acclimatisation period is understandable and so are away defeats to high-quality opponents. But the least you expect is to be outclassed on occasion by brilliant skill, rather than undone by two or three simple lapses in concentration that turn a potential point into another defeat.
Sheffield United

Paul Heckingbottom wanted a little luck, and he has found some. In midweek, the independent VAR panel (a different rant, but: I have no idea what the point is of having people reviewing something that has already been decided three days after the incident and making those findings public) ruled that Sheffield United should not have been awarded their last-minute winning penalty against Wolves. This weekend, a Brighton player got himself sent off and gave Heckingbottom’s team the impetus.
Related Article
Sheffield United have chosen profit over fans with a season of record-breakingly bad football

All season, Heckingbottom has been asking his players to be braver in possession. He can accept things will go wrong, but he cannot accept players cowering in a proverbial corner when their team needs them, as in the 8-0 home defeat to Newcastle.

At the Amex, his players did that. They were attempting to push forward even before the red card, after the manager had instructed his players to stop playing back to the goalkeeper for Wes Foderingham to hit the ball long and lose possession. With a man advantage, Sheffield United found those spaces, played progressive passes and were unfortunate not to win consecutive Premier League games.

Who knows if any of this is sustainable, but Heckingbottom et al face Bournemouth (home) and Burnley (away) after the international break. The headline news is that the manager will make it through the break with his job intact. Those games offer a chance to improve after a wretched start to the season.

title: No Newcastle fan would have argued with Kieran Trippier last season – something has changed
lead: The injury crisis and busy schedule hampering Newcastle’s ambition has left the club and fanbase in a funk
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: This is an extract of The Score. Click the sign-up box below to receive the newsletter every Monday morning this season for Daniel Storey’s verdict on all 20 Premier League clubs

The energy is running out and the impact of last season’s impressive Champions League qualification is becoming increasingly apparent. The danger is that Newcastle lose out both ways. They are bottom of their Champions League group and are favourites to stay there ahead of a trip to Paris that could eliminate them from the knockout stages.

Eddie Howe’s team have played four games on the weekends after their Champions League fixtures and have dropped points in three of them. At Wolves, they were lucky to escape with a point. At West Ham the same, albeit with their opponents looking equally blunted by midweek commitments. At Bournemouth on Saturday, Newcastle lost 2-0 and Nick Pope was their best player.

It isn’t just the fatigue in those who do play. The rapid increase in midweek matches and subsequent lack of recovery time has clearly played a role in Newcastle’s injury crisis. They were without nine players at Bournemouth, Miguel Almiron went off injured and they have no fit strikers. It’s a point we’ve raised before, but having all those full-backs but relying upon Callum Wilson’s fitness over a 50-game season was simply too risky.
Related Article
Newcastle in contact with brains behind Spurs' £1.2bn stadium over St James' Park redevelopment

“We couldn’t be where we needed to be for it,” Eddie Howe said after the game. “In and out of possession we were unrecognisable. They’re such honest players and they’ve given me so much that I’m absolutely clear I have to support them.”

Howe is clearly right, if a little resigned. You can’t simply magic energy back into your squad by repeatedly listening to Jake Humphrey’s High Performance Podcast. The only answer is for Newcastle to cope or, as is more likely, fall into the Europa League or worse and focus on the Premier League.

More interesting is how this season is playing out amongst an element of the club’s supporters. Changes to the club’s ticketing system means that there are newer faces in the away end this year, and Newcastle have only won one of their six away league games.

At full-time on Saturday evening, Kieran Trippier argued with one supporter who was clearly giving the team grief. That simply wouldn’t have happened last season because everybody was supporting everybody else. It’s worth keeping an eye on any foolish entitlement growing.
