title: How Norwich City lost their way
lead: The Canaries are sliding towards irrelevance – it’s time to change the owners, manager and academy ethos
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: At Carrow Road, the pervading sense is an unnerving one: that everything and nothing are changing all at once. Mark Attanasio, the owner of Major League Baseball franchise Milwaukee Brewers, has taken a stake and is looking to increase it, but Delia Smith and Michael Wynn Jones are still there.

Sporting director Stuart Webber announced his departure in June and will finally leave the club after Saturday’s away trip to Cardiff. David Wagner has lost eight of his last 10 games, but still hasn’t been sacked. All the while, the club tumbles lower.

It’s not that long since Norwich City were the good news story of English football. They had the forward-thinking sporting director and the young German coach. They retained their “little Norwich” tag as a badge of honour but won the Championship title with 94 points and then took the brave call not to squander the Premier League’s bestowed wealth. When they were promoted again, this time with 97 points, Norwich had cracked it.

Nice try, weakling. Instead, Norwich are learning English football’s two relentless truths: the financial non-elite are not insured against repeated mistakes and, if you are unable to intervene and arrest those mistakes, the floor is far lower than you trick yourself into believing at the time. Two years after promotion, the club’s Supporters Trust are warning of widespread fan disaffection and apathy over the inertia that they believe has afflicted every element of the club.
Related Article
The fan-owned football club where refugees, the homeless and prison inmates are welcome

Inevitably, those problems start at the top. Attanasio’s investment may well bring extra spending power; Norwich need it. Theirs has been a self-funding model that relies upon continued success and thus places extra pressure upon it. Within that model, you are only as good as the recruitment decisions you make in key positions.

For a while, Webber appeared to be the blue-eyed boy. There are still plenty within the club’s fanbase who would commend him for his work. Webber oversaw the promotion campaigns and the investment in the club’s training ground and academy cannot be overlooked. These can become statements of a bright future.

But a fine sporting director must establish, oversee and maintain an identity of how the club will operate, a successful recruitment model (spoiler: buying low and selling high) and a succession plan for the departure of players, managers and themselves.

As for the identity, it’s hard to say. Norwich effectively pivoted their entire strategy from one Premier League to the next, spending a little before spending a lot (although perhaps that was the strategy). It might well have worked if the recruited players had worked out, but most were an abject failure. Milot Rashica and Christos Tzolis were the two most expensive signings and barely had an impact. Josh Sargent came next and is still there. Ozan Kabak was an expensive and dismal loanee. Norwich spent all that money and got one extra point.

Look at the sales of players for more than £5m during Webber’s six-year tenure – there are nine. Five of those players were academy graduates (Andrew Omobamidele, Max Aarons, Josh Murphy, Jacob Murphy, Jamal Lewis), developed before his arrival. Three were signed before Webber’s time (Alex Pritchard, James Maddison, Ben Godfrey). Emi Buendia was the only player signed under Webber’s recruitment who was sold for significant profit (albeit it was a vast fee, Norwich’s record sale).

Then we come to managers, whose departure and appointment enables a club to commit to a philosophy that can guide the rest of their business. Daniel Farke, who twice took Norwich up, was sacked after three months of his second Premier League season having just won his first game. His replacement Dean Smith failed badly, a 29 per cent win ratio and a sacking two days after Christmas during last season. Wagner, Webber’s man from Huddersfield Town, started brightly but has tailed off alarmingly since – 24 points from his last 26 league matches. From Farke to Smith to Wagner also represents two lurches in playing style.
Related Article
It's time for Man Utd to sack Erik ten Hag

“This was, I think, where we went badly wrong,” says Norwich supporter Matt Wallace. “There was always this belief that succession had been planned. We had developed players and a style and a culture and a mentality, but then Smith ran counter to all of those things. The style of play was utterly different, and the attitude to the fans was dismissive when we made our feelings known.

“It felt like everything Webber had said to this point about what type of club to avoid, we were turning into. Smith was sacked by Villa after Farke lost his Norwich job, so what was the succession plan? The pivot to Wagner reinforced this. Three managers with different styles and visions, and a sporting director is supposed to smooth over these differences and help provide consistency.”

In these circumstances, Championship clubs are left with two things. The first is a set of questions that attempt to imply blame: were the owners too hands-off or too parsimonious? Was Webber not focused enough in his work or let down by the club’s lack of investment? Were the managerial appointments logical ones that went wrong (their fault) or illogical ones that were destined to fail (Webber’s fault)? There are no easy answers and supporters will disagree on all. That only provokes further discord.

Secondly, financial strife becomes inevitable. Norwich spent post-Covid-19 in the Premier League and they came straight back down. Norwich were relegated and had parachute payments to assist a third promotion campaign, but fell way short. Last week, the club announced annual losses of £27m and the three-year FFP limit is £35m. Players have been sold to help next year’s books – Omobamidele and Aarons raised around £20m – but it’s hard to know who is next. There is no Maddison, no Buendia to sell as a crown jewel.

For several years, the question surrounding Norwich City was whether they could break out of their up-down purgatory, to which the answer is usually: yes, but not how you’d like. Let a yo-yo take its natural course and it will end up at the bottom, not the top. It’s so hard to keep getting everything right when you are acutely aware of what happens if you don’t.

Norwich are now crying out for something far greater – reinvention. The ownership may have to change and the overhaul of their recruitment must. They need more from an academy that now faces pressure to raise revenue as well as first-team players. They need to find a manager who fits in with what new sporting director Ben Knapper believes in and they have to make sure it’s the right one this time. Otherwise Norwich face a more certain future: comparative irrelevance at the end of a dying dream.

title: It’s time for Man Utd to sack Erik ten Hag
lead: United should not just be questioning whether they should axe Ten Hag – they ought to be scratching their heads as to why they ever appointed him
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Erik ten Hag has been talking an awful lot about fighting recently: pre-match and post-match, when Manchester United lose (more often) and when they win (less often), at an awards ceremony the other night.

All the talk is of fight and togetherness, togetherness and fight and fighting together. You can’t deny this team’s ability to punch itself in the face and shoot itself in the foot, but that’s probably not what Ten Hag meant.

On some basic level, this all clearly makes sense. It is managerial 101: you demand more from a group that is underperforming and it is always best to talk in vague intangibles. Fight. Morale. Unity. Intensity. Fire. “Play like you mean it,” read the banner in the away end at Fulham; supporters want exactly the same thing.

There are two problems with this, though. Firstly, the moment a manager asks for more fight is the moment they reveal that they have lost more than a little control. Were they demanding more efficient finishing, a straighter offside line or putting more accurate crosses into the box, fine – these are technical issues that players are at least partly responsible for. But fight is a non-negotiable and as such is ever present under a high-performing coach. You’re inadvertently saying more about yourself than them.
Related Article
Sir Jim Ratcliffe won't sack Erik ten Hag but Man Utd boss will lose transfer powers

The second problem is that United’s problem isn’t really a lack of fight, it’s a lack of playing good football at either end of the pitch and in midfield. You have Harry Maguire and Jonny Evans as your centre-backs, Bruno Fernandes getting riled every time a teammate makes a mistake, Antony coming off the bench to barge into and kick people and then blame them for it because that’s apparently what £80m buys you now. There’s enough fighters, just not enough functioning footballers.

The first accusation is always of downed tools and it’s almost always nonsense. I refuse to believe that Manchester United aren’t trying; what they aren’t is doing, or at least doing often enough: tracking runs, playing the right pass, not slowing the game down, communicating with each other, keeping their heads, overlapping on opponents and doubling up if a teammate needs help.

They aren’t creative enough to create chances against good teams and aren’t durable enough to stop good teams creating chances against them. Let’s be real: they are a bad football team, given their resources.

How much of this is down to the manager is more open to interpretation at this club than most, perhaps even any other. The decay of the Glazers hangs over Old Trafford like Sauron’s eye. It haunts every dream and makes every day at least a little bit harder. The part-purchase by Sir Jim Ratcliffe may well allow for infrastructure improvements at Old Trafford, which itself is a statue to the club’s metaphorical decomposition. Until then, everything is compromised.

But none of this a watertight excuse for Ten Hag’s underperformance this season. If the ownership reduces the ceiling on the club’s potential, Ten Hag is busy taking it towards the floor. It feels uncharitable to keep harking back to David Moyes’ season – now a decade ago – like some ghastly control experiment of United’s ill-health, but that was then the nadir. In 2013-14, Moyes lost nine of his first 35 matches. This season under Ten Hag, United have lost nine of 17.

To aid the implementation of Ten Hag’s tactical plan, he has been permitted to oversee recruitment policy (if not quite being handed the keys to the club, the manager has at least sat behind the wheel). United’s major purchases followed a trend.

The club pursued Frenkie de Jong and Jurrien Timber and signed Lisandro Martinez, Antony, Sofyan Amrabat and Andre Onana – all had played under Ten Hag before. Ten Hag pushed hard for Mason Mount too, who is now out of the team. They have spent over £400m in 18 months for him and they are no better than they were.

All this could have a purpose. United paid sky-high prices for many of these signings, but if Ten Hag was intent on replicating the style that had previously made him so successful, recruiting his disciples might help.

So when Ten Hag said last month that “the football that we played at Ajax, we will never play here”, several alarms sounded. Why, in that case, are you buying players who excelled in that system? And why were you appointed if not to implement your previously successful philosophy? Did they just see a bald manager who spoke well and dreamt of Pep?
Related Article
The fan-owned football club where refugees, the homeless and prison inmates are welcome
There is indeed a sense of foreboding that now accompanies every period of Manchester United in adversity.

Once that was the opposite, an accumulation of pressure by a super-team that identified and exploited cracks like nobody else could. Now they crumble and collapse. But that doesn’t represent a lack of fight, more a lack of belief. This is a land of broken spirits and fractured hope.

Ten Hag must accept blame for this drastic loss of confidence. There was the lack of clarity over Mason Greenwood’s future and the temporary omission and subsequent return of Antony after accusations of domestic abuse, which the player has denied.

Couple that with the complete exclusion of Jadon Sancho, public censure of Marcus Rashford and continued absence of Raphael Varane and it creates the impression – fair or otherwise – that Ten Hag has his favourites. That can fragment a dressing room when they simultaneously lack obvious tactical direction.

But more than all of that, United are just drastically uninspiring. They are a football team who their own fans don’t like watching. They are interesting only when they are shambolic. They were handed a Champions League draw with the weakest team in pot three and may well finish bottom of the group. They have lost consecutive Old Trafford games by three or more goals for just the third time in the club’s history. They are closer in points to the Premier League’s bottom six than its top four.

There were logical reasons to appoint Ten Hag: the tactical nous, the fresh energy, the recent success, the development of younger players. Each one of those has been dismantled over the last four months. So too have the reasons to keep him in charge. Having multiple problems at a club, some of them unsolvable, is no reason not to correct a growing mistake that you can change more easily.

title: Everton’s takeover takes crucial next step in latest sign club’s fortunes are changing
lead: Prospective new owners 777 are increasingly confident the deal could finally be sealed in the next 12 weeks
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: It is precisely the right time for Sean Dyche to be flexing his managerial muscles as Everton gear up for regime change.

Despite the pleasantries that are usually expressed when a takeover is confirmed, new owners and incumbent head coaches rarely make comfortable bed fellows. Gary O’Neil lasted six months under a new regime at Bournemouth while at Birmingham City John Eustace was fired after four.

With sources telling Informfully that 777 Partners remain hopeful of completing their buy out within their initial 12-week timeline, Everton’s recent resurgence under Dyche is a timely reminder of his managerial heft. Despite off-field turbulence, financial travails and a miniscule transfer budget, he has quietly returned the club’s reputation for being tough to beat.

It has all been playing out in front of the club’s would-be owners, who have watched several games, have already met Dyche and director of football Kevin Thelwell and plan a detailed audit of football operations when they get the keys to Goodison Park. If their optimism is to be believed, that would be in time for the start of 2024 and potentially at a point where they could help the Everton manager add to his squad in the January transfer window.
Related Article
The fan-owned football club where refugees, the homeless and prison inmates are welcome
Last week their prospective buy-out passed the first – albeit most straightforward – of the three tests it needs to satisfy if it is to be ratified in time for the turn of the year.

After completing weeks of detailed suitability checks, the Football Association gave the green light for 777 co-founders Josh Wander and Steven Pasko to become directors at the club if their takeover is permitted by the Premier League.

They still require ratification from the Financial Conduct Authority and to pass the Premier League’s own version of the Owners and Directors tests, which include providing proof of financial resources and business plans for each of the next three seasons.

Those who are sceptical about the group’s finances and their track record at the other clubs in their multi-club model point out that these rigorous checks will provide the biggest examination of the Miami-based group’s credentials.

It also emerged last week that vastly experienced former Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, who was pictured in the director’s box at Goodison Park during the Carabao Cup win over Burnley last week, has been drafted in by 777 to help advise them on the takeover process.

There is still a lot of water to pass under the bridge before any change of ownership can be confirmed. The club are still waiting for an independent commission’s verdict on the hearing into alleged Financial Fair Play breaches which could carry a points deduction, heavy fine or transfer embargo if proved.
Related Article
Newcastle and Everton interested as Kalvin Phillips set to leave Man City in January

Sources still believe it will be “a few weeks” before they know which way the commission has decided – but it’s understood that 777 Partners have factored every eventuality into their due diligence. If a fine or sporting sanction is handed down it is likely to impact the price they pay Farhad Moshiri.
On the field there are real signs of progress under Dyche. Insiders talk of Everton rediscovering their identity and of a team that resonates with the support because of its commitment to hard work.

While much was made of them having only 20 per cent of possession in last week’s draw with Brighton, it was not the full story. Everton created more chances and were unlucky not to win against a team heavily fancied to do well this season.
Dyche’s coaching has also coaxed the best from a revived Abdoulaye Doucoure, while Jarrad Branthwaite’s form has been so good a potential England call-up has been talked about.

At one point the 21-year-old centre-back was talked about as another example of Everton’s confused player development pathway. Signed for £1m from Carlisle as an 18-year-old, there was a fear he would be lost in the system as Everton managers groped for a way to simply keep their heads above water.
Now, with Dyche’s steady hand at the tiller, he is proof of what can be achieved with good scouting and a coaching staff with a clear plan. It is a clear message for the potential owners.

title: Newcastle may be forced to rip up January transfer strategy as injury crisis bites
lead: Eddie Howe has never wanted quick fixes but Newcastle’s latest Champions League defeat laid bare how thin their squad has become
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Dan Ashworth wisely ruled himself out of the mess that is Manchester United last week, but anyone who feels he is taking an easy option by committing to Newcastle United is mistaken.
The towering project at St James’ Park is approaching a pivotal phase and their Champions League travails inevitably put Ashworth’s role in the spotlight.

It is a club with the ambition and potential resources to believe they can challenge the continent’s best but bruising back-to-back defeats against Borussia Dortmund illustrate how far they still have to travel. The club’s owners are patient and understanding but inevitably a summer when they spent £130m only to collide with an acute injury crisis by autumn will come into sharp focus.

Did they take their eye off the ball by looking to the future too much with moves for Lewis Hall and Tino Livramento? Ashworth will argue not given Livramento’s brilliant start in black and white but it feels as if January might be the right time to relax the remit and give Eddie Howe a helping hand with some short-term fixes.
Related Article
Newcastle in contact with brains behind Spurs' £1.2bn stadium over St James' Park redevelopment

Newcastle have been reluctant to do that so far and one United source told Informfully that the way the club is run would make it “impossible” to suddenly start arguing the case for bringing in a crop of established 29-year-olds on big wages.

“Kieran Trippier shows there is flexibility for the right player but (owners) PIF are process-driven. They want to know the long-term value of investments in everything – and that includes player recruitment,” a source said.
In other words, a black and white version of Wout Weghorst is not on his way to St James’ Park.

Ashworth is the man charged with pulling all these strands together and January will be his most challenging transfer window yet. His recruitment team are tracking Blackburn’s Adam Wharton, for example, but is the 19-year-old really a solution right now?

Sources admit to Informfully there was a measure of tension last summer between those competing priorities, whether to invest in the future or focus on the present. And while there is wiggle room in January – especially in the loan market – there’s no easy recruitment route to navigate if Newcastle want New Year signings.

Howe is no short-termist but many of his picks have revealed a longing for “right here, right now”‘ solutions. One of them last summer was Scott McTominay, not the most glamorous name but a player with a CV burnished by experience on the Champions League and international stage.

That particular move made no sense when Manchester United put a laughable £40m asking price on him but we can expect Howe to privately push for players who would arrive ready to plug in and play in January. Manchester City’s Kalvin Phillips is one such option. Al-Hilal’s Ruben Neves is another, although new rules to block loans between affiliated clubs are set to be introduced. Informfully can confirm Premier League clubs will vote on 21 November to apply an interim ban in time for the January transfer window.

Where Ashworth and the club’s owners go next will tell us so much. So far they have managed to satisfy both aims with moves for the likes of Anthony Gordon and Sandro Tonali, but the latter’s long suspension for illegal gambling shows that even the best laid plans can go awry.

For Howe, the task now is to ensure Newcastle’s season stays on track before January arrives. Against Borussia Dortmund the result was bad but the performance wasn’t. Considering their stretched resources, Newcastle have been unfortunate to emerge from the two games with nothing.
Related Article
Newcastle consider loan move for Man City outcast Kalvin Phillips with Sandro Tonali facing ban

Now it’ll be a case of counting heads for Bournemouth on Saturday and then after the international break, it’s 10 games in 36 days with both Champions League and Carabao Cup fates to be decided before the New Year.
Home games against Chelsea and Manchester United offer the opportunity to strike blows against top four rivals but with just 16 senior outfield players available they are seriously stretched.
Thursday could bring a further complication as Informfully understands that Gareth Southgate is likely to call up Anthony Gordon, who has been Newcastle’s dynamo in recent weeks.

While that would undoubtedly represent vindication for the Magpies’ sales pitch to Gordon when they signed him, it is a mixed blessing. Newcastle would ideally like to give him a fortnight to rest and recuperate.

It was certainly telling that the Newcastle manager confessed Tuesday’s game had simply come “too soon” for Gordon after his Arsenal exertions pushed him firmly into the red zone where players risk injury from over exertion.

With Callum Wilson requiring careful protection and a personally tailored training programme to prevent a recurrence of his hamstring issues, Newcastle could end up very short in attacking areas. In an emergency Howe could break the glass and give the club’s former number nine Joelinton a run of games up front but removing him from midfield undoubtedly diminishes the club’s engine room options.
That is just one of the questions with no perfect answer rebounding around St James’ Park right now.
Five January options
Kalvin Phillips
Out of favour Manchester City midfielder is a perfect loan option for Newcastle and would arrive with the right mentality and ability to immediately improve them. Howe is a big fan of the player.
Amadou Onana
Everton midfielder has attracted plenty of interest from rival Premier League clubs but no-one was willing to take the plunge in the summer. A long-term solution but he would not come cheap.
Ruben Neves

Do Newcastle have the appetite for a potential fight with their Premier League rivals? A loan move for a player playing in Saudi Arabia would prompt a huge debate but Ashworth made it clear last week they are potentially prepared to go there.
Tammy Abraham

Callum Wilson signed a contract extension but Informfully understands the club have begun the process of scouting strikers. Abraham, approaching the end of a long injury exile, is available as Roma look to balance their books.
Rayan Cherki

Ashworth’s job is to ensure Newcastle are in the market for the best prospects and Cherki is one. Like Desire Doue at Stade Rennais, the Magpies are keeping tabs but January might be too early and expensive.

title: Newcastle lose at Dortmund as another harsh lesson leaves uphill task in Champions League
lead: Premier League clubs may now borrow Dortmund’s blueprint to exploit a Newcastle side that are starting to look stretched
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Borussia Dortmund 2-0 Newcastle United (Fullkrug 26′, Brandt 79′)
SIGNAL IDUNA PARK —  Ailing Newcastle United are on life support in their Champions League group of death.
In a mirror image of their European campaign so far, they had moments at a bouncing, boisterous Signal Iduna Park, but their more seasoned opponents always seemed to have the momentum.
Eddie Howe’s side have been progressing at lightning pace over the last two years, but exposure to the Champions League gold standard has illustrated that they’ve still got a way to go.
Related Article
Newcastle in contact with brains behind Spurs' £1.2bn stadium over St James' Park redevelopment

So far this has been a campaign of harsh defeats and even harsher lessons for Eddie Howe and his European greenhorns. Scratch their mind-bending night against Paris Saint-Germain out of the equation and it has been their Champions League story – a team making a big noise domestically looking strangely subdued on the biggest stage in the game.
The frustration that will follow Howe out of the Ruhr is that this patched-up version of Newcastle are a pastiche of the side that he had hoped to roll out in this group of heavyweights.

The Magpies couldn’t even fill their bench at Borussia Dortmund and most of those that Howe could call upon were hardly game changers. He included two goalkeepers and academy kids Lucas De Bolle and Ben Parkinson, names that would have left even Newcastle die-hards scrambling for Google for research purposes. Lewis Miley, aged 17 with just 45 minutes in the League Cup on his CV before Tuesday night, looked like a veritable veteran.

Afterwards a deflated Howe admitted that Newcastle lacked their trademark intensity. He picks his words carefully, so it was a loaded admission when he said they lacked quality and “weren’t at their best”.
He was right to say that on their best day even this injury-depleted version of Newcastle would have had enough to emerge from this game with a point or more to cling to.

As it is, they lost because they ceded the big moments. Joelinton has been colossal for Newcastle since Howe repurposed him in midfield but his two misses – particularly the second-half header that he screwed wide when Tino Livramento teed him up with a wonderful cross – were desperate.

What a time this was for the Brazilian’s composure to desert him. In the first half Newcastle found themselves flailing a bit when Fabian Schar sprang a defensive wall of bright yellow with a lofted pass, but Joelinton couldn’t pull the ball down with a clear sight of goal.
It is those fine margins that Newcastle have been on the wrong side of over two bruising encounters against Dortmund.

Credit to Edin Terzic, a manager who had a brief spell as a coach at West Ham a couple of years back. He hailed it as a “big achievement” to do the double on Newcastle but it was the way his team were able to negate Newcastle’s strengths in both games by flooding the midfield with craft, legs and graft which edged both games.

Not many Premier League managers have got the best of Howe twice in a season, but he has. You wonder whether a few more will now borrow his blueprint to exploit a Newcastle side that are starting to look stretched.
Related Article
Newcastle and Everton interested as Kalvin Phillips set to leave Man City in January

Borussia Dortmund are also the first team to exploit Jamaal Lascelles’ weaknesses and puncture Kieran Trippier’s trademark composure. Without that defensive foundation, Newcastle looked diminished and had it not been for Nick Pope’s flawless reflexes they would have been ahead before Niclas Fullkrug reacted first to Marcel Sabitzer’s smart pull-back.
With the exception of the four goals against PSG, Newcastle are yet to score in this competition and Callum Wilson had just nine touches before being withdrawn with tightness in his hamstring.
Anthony Gordon – in the red zone after pouring everything into overhauling Arsenal – was named on the bench and they missed his energy early on.

The second, terminal goal for Newcastle came after Trippier’s free-kick failed to beat the first man. They had committed too many men forward, Borussia Dortmund broke, and Julian Brandt swept past Pope. It was typical of the sort of carelessness which is likely to cost them progression in this competition.

title: Emma Raducanu is back doing long sessions on court – but her comeback date remains a mystery
lead: The 20-year-old has been back working hard at the National Tennis Centre but is still some weeks away from a comeback
author: James Gray

body.text: COPPER BOX ARENA — Emma Raducanu was grinding on Friday.

As GB’s Billie Jean King Cup team beamed to a few hundred schoolchildren at the Copper Box, which is sold out this weekend for their clash with Sweden, Informfully understands Raducanu was on court at the National Tennis Centre for a 90-minute session.
It is a sign of the stepping up of her rehabilitation process from the triple surgery, one on her ankle and one on each wrist, that ended her season in May.
But it is understood that the date of her exact comeback is yet to be decided.

Some of the money being thrown at the Brisbane International might have been offered her way, but when they announced their star-studded start list this week, there was no Raducanu to be seen: Naomi Osaka, six months after giving birth, Andy Murray on perhaps his last tour of Australia and world No 10 Holger Rune will all command significant appearance fees, so perhaps there was no budget left for Raducanu.
Related Article
Andy Murray splits with long-time coach Ivan Lendl for a third time

The more likely target would seem to be Auckland, which will run from 1 January in 2024, although it was also the scene of the 2021 US Open champion’s ankle injury last year, rolling the joint on an indoor court that drew criticism throughout the draw. But an existing relationship with the organisers may prove enough for her to garner a wildcard: with a protected ranking in the 80s, she may need one.
But if her body is not ready, there is no question of rushing into anything. In two years since winning the US Open, she has played just 51 matches and won less than half of them.

Meanwhile, the British team are getting used to life without Raducanu, and instead trying to make a name for themselves. Sweden, stripped of their two best players by injury, do not have another singles player ranked inside the top 350, meaning the sold-out Copper Box will be expecting a convincing victory.
“There’s absolutely no room for [complacency], and I think we’ve seen in this competition that anything’s possible,” said team captain Anne Keothavong.

The skipper also reiterated that there was no credit in the bank for the likes of Harriet Dart, Heather Watson and Katie Boulter, who defied expectations by coming within a tie-break of the final last year in Glasgow.

With Raducanu edging closer to fitness and a strong Junior BJK Cup side that is into the semi-finals in Cordoba, competition for places is a luxury that a team who only dug themselves out of the Europe-Africa Group 1 in 2019 has not come to expect.
“I don’t think anyone can guarantee a spot on this team,” Keothavong added, skirting the question of whether Raducanu would walk back in when fit and ready.
“They set the bar high for the others who want to be on this team, which is good.
“But everyone’s hungry and everyone wants to be part of that, so for me as captain, hopefully, we’ll be spoilt for choice.”
GB vs Sweden
(Winner will go into a qualifying tie next spring for a place at the 2024 BJK Cup Finals)
Saturday 11 November (from 2pm)
Sunday 12 November (from 12pm)
Watch live on the BBC Sport website, app and iPlayer
And Keothavong is confident that the next Raducanu isn’t far away either.
She also said: “I think British women’s tennis is in a much better place than it has been for a long time.

“The likes of Mika Stojsavljevic, Hannah Klugman, Mimi Xu have showed in recent weeks what they’re capable of at the ITF Challenger events and they’re only going to get better. They’re obviously limited with the number of tournaments they can play.

“But we need that in British tennis across men’s and women’s tennis, competition and fight for places that is only going to raise the level of everyone. And in a training environment as well, they’re all going to be pushing against each other and challenging each other. And that’s the only way you’re going to improve.
“If we can create that kind of environment within British tennis, then it’s only a good thing.”

title: Andy Murray splits with long-time coach Ivan Lendl for a third time
lead: The 63-year-old Czech coach has been in charge for all of Murray’s greatest triumphs and wished his former colleague ‘only the best in the years to come’
author: James Gray

body.text: Andy Murray has split with his long-time coach Ivan Lendl after a bad-tempered end to his 2023 tour season.

Murray, who won all three of his grand slam titles with Lendl in his corner, brought the former Czech player back into his coaching set-up in March last year as he attempted to recapture his best form in this post-hip surgery part of his career.
However, the 63-year-old was rarely seen outside of grand slams with other members of the coaching staff bearing the brunt of the travel, which Lendl is known to be keen on avoiding.
“Ivan has been by my side at the biggest moments in my career and I can’t thank him enough for all that he’s helped me achieve,” said Murray.
“He’s a unique character, who understands what it takes to win and I’ve learnt an awful lot over the years from him.”
Related Article
Emma Raducanu could silence haters at Olympics next year but her chance to qualify is now slim

Lendl himself said: “I will look back with some great memories of the time Andy and I worked together. He’s as hard a worker as there is and the sport is better because of him. I wish him only the best in the years to come.”

i understands Murray may spend some more time over the off-season working on technical elements with Louis Cayer, the LTA’s senior performance advisor, but his travelling coaching team is expected to remain largely the same.
The 36-year-old will continue to work with Mark Hilton, Dan Evans’s former coach, and doubles specialist Jonny O’Mara, whom he hired ahead of the grass-court season earlier this year.

Lendl first started working with Murray at the end of 2011, at which point he had reached three grand slam finals but never won one. It was reminiscent of Lendl’s own career, in which he lost his first four grand slam finals but ended up with eight major titles.

A man of few words, what he did say seemed to make the difference. Within eight months of working together Murray was Olympic champion and a month later had the US Open title too. The next season he finally cracked the Wimbledon hoodoo, becoming the first British man in 77 years to win at SW19.

They split in 2014 but got back together in 2016, a reconciliation that heralded another Wimbledon title and another Olympic gold medal, although typically Lendl was not present in the flesh in Rio de Janeiro.

Their third spell together has been nowhere near as successful: winning the Challenger title in Nottingham can probably be regarded as the peak, which pales in significance compared to previous triumphs.

Lendl’s departure this time, understood to be at Murray’s instigation, is a recognition that time is running out. He ended his tour season in Paris with yet another defeat to Alex de Minaur, having been 5-2 up in the deciding set. He destroyed a racket in frustration on the court, and reportedly another once he reached the locker room.
He will head to Malaga in two weeks for the Davis Cup Finals and a meeting with Serbia, before a much-needed off-season with Cayer and the rest of his regular crew. It might end up being his last.

title: Arsenal should start wondering why they didn’t spend £30m on James Ward-Prowse
lead: The 29-year-old midfielder’s skillset makes him a valuable asset to any squad, as his all-round performance on Thursday night showed
author: James Gray

body.text: Is James Ward-Prowse overrated or underrated? It has been the topic of conversation so often over the years that it is tricky to work out which way the pendulum is currently swinging.

Certainly England boss Gareth Southgate does not have him in the top echelon after, for the sixth time in a row, the 29-year-old was not selected for his country despite two dead rubbers against Malta and North Macedonia. And when he became available for just £30m last summer, David Moyes was just about the only one interested.

But how many of Mikel Arteta, Eddie Howe, Ange Postecoglou and Jurgen Klopp are looking at their respective midfields, particularly in terms of depth, and wondering how big a gap Ward-Prowse could have filled?

In particular Arteta’s difficulties replacing the injured Martin Odegaard (or providing effective rotation for him) have been laid bare. Emile Smith Rowe, Kai Havertz, Jorginho, Fabio Vieira and Thomas Partey have all failed in various ways to fill in for the captain. Ward-Prowse’s tenacity would show them up, you suspect.
He might not have started every game for Arsenal or any other top-tier side, but as the fixture list starts to grind, there will be a few green-eyed monsters looking to the London Stadium.
Related Article
Our verdict on all 20 Premier League teams after Gameweek 11

Ward-Prowse was like a pig in mud on Thursday night as West Ham laboured to a 1-0 win over Olympiakos. Firstly, Moyes’s classic counter-attackers were on the front foot, giving him the chance to pick passes with the majority of possession and plenty of dead-ball opportunities.

Secondly, Olympiakos appeared to have missed his corner-taking ability off their scouting report, as they gave West Ham attackers the run of the box when the ball went behind. It was only through Nayef Aguerd’s profligacy, hitting the target once – and then straight at the keeper – from his three first-half chances, that Ward-Prowse did not have an assist before the break.
“He practises a lot,” reveals team-mate Lukasz Fabianski, captain for the night on Thursday.
“I think when it comes to set-piece takers, the main thing for players like that it’s being consistent in training, so you have to work on it almost every single day.
“That’s the main reason why he hits it so well and why he always puts it in the right place.
“Almost every corner that we had, we had a pretty decent chance from it. Being consistent over the years always helps you to be at that level.”

'That's the difference between us and those at the top of the table'James Ward-Prowse talks consistency in the Premier League after their 1-0 win in the #UEL!🎙️ @lynseyhipgrave1 | @CarltonCole1 pic.twitter.com/KW4sWIGEaR

And then there was the shithousery. Ward-Prowse is a master of gamesmanship in midfield, never afraid of rolling the ball away from an opponent’s free-kick when the referee isn’t looking or having a few extra words with a notoriously fiery opponent.
Edson Alvarez, returning from suspension on Thursday and back in the book again, could learn from his subtlety because Ward-Prowse is a gadfly of a player who is hard to swat away with conviction.

There was spice against Olympiakos, the Hammers keen to avenge a defeat in Athens that they felt their opponents enjoyed a little too much. When Lucas Paqueta ran over to the Greek fans to celebrate in front of them, Ward-Prowse was one of the first to join him.
“There was fire in our bellies. It was difficult in the first half, but we dug deep in the second half and got our reward,” Ward-Prowse said.

“You have highs and lows in football, we made a positive start and felt unbeatable really. We have had a slump but you’re gonna get that – that’s the difference between the top teams and the rest, they have the consistency.
“Tonight is a huge win for us and the first step in gathering some momentum.”

Much of that momentum came from the Englishman’s perfectly weighted pass – played from such a straight angle that there was almost no margin for error – that allowed Paqueta to spring the offside trap and volley home. Ward-Prowse now has four Europa League assists, the joint-most of anyone in the entire competition as well as the joint-most key passes.

His Premier League stats don’t quite stack up in the same way, and that will forever be the criticism, that he does not influence big games: he could not stop Southampton going down last season (although he did bag nine league goals and four assists along the way) and after a roaring start to his West Ham career, is without a domestic goal contribution since 16 September.
Perhaps Moyes, results notwithstanding, would prefer it that way, in case an injury-struck Champions League manager gets any ideas in January. They could do a lot worse than Ward-Prowse.

title: The Score: Our chief football writer’s verdict on all 20 Premier League teams after Gameweek 12
lead: Injuries threaten Spurs and Newcastle’s fortunes, Harry Maguire’s renaissance and Arsenal’s striker dilemma
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Click the sign-up box below to receive The Score newsletter every Monday morning this season
This is threatening to be the most chaotic season in a long time. Not only has the VAR circus and a spate of muscle injuries made things weird, we also have five teams separated by two points.
Aston Villa, who lost at Nottingham Forest last week, are now two points behind the Manchester City team we thought might run away with the league and nothing makes sense anymore.

At the bottom, none of the promoted clubs won again, so Bournemouth were the big winners after beating a laboured Newcastle team. The Cherries’ former manager is having fun too: Gary O’Neil’s Wolves scored two injury-time goals to beat Tottenham.
This weekend’s results
Saturday
Sunday
If there’s one team sinking into trouble as we break for internationals, might it be Fulham? They have won twice since the opening day and look chronically short of goals…
Read my analysis on every team below (listed in table order).
Man City

While Erling Haaland was obviously ecstatic at winning the Gerd Muller Trophy at the Ballon d’Or as Europe’s highest scoring player, there were shots of the player looking a bit sultry after the ceremony. And you can understand why: he had just been victim to football’s most high-profile robbery since Bobby Moore was accused of stealing a £625 diamond and emerald bracelet at the 1970 World Cup.

The Norwegian had plundered 52 goals in 53 games, a record-crushing 36 in the Premier League and 12 in the Champions League while winning the Treble, all in his debut season aged only 22. Lionel Messi had won the World Cup, granted, and a few trophies in France, but had he not been Lionel Messi there would be no question. Haaland would have been crowned No 1, not little-remembered second place.
Related Article
Haaland’s genius cancelled out by late Palmer penalty as Chelsea hold Man City in thriller

He may never win a Treble again, will probably never win a World Cup or European Championship with Norway, but more goal-scoring records will tumble. Twenty goals in 21 games this season, his two against Chelsea moving him to 49 goals in 47 Premier League games. After being quicker to 10, 20, 30 and 40 Premier League goals than any other striker, if he scores once in the next 17 games he will beat Andy Cole’s record of half-a-century of top-flight goals in 65 games, besting the very best to have played in England, including Alan Shearer and Ruud van Nistelrooy.
And there is so much more to him than merely goals. For Haaland and City’s first, it was clever No 9 play to win the penalty. Because — let’s be honest — it was clearly won.

Haaland and Marc Cucurella had as much of each other’s shirts before the City striker burst in front of the Chelsea defender before going down. It’s hard to believe Cucurella would even have the strength to wrestle Haaland to the floor if he tried. By Sam Cunningham.
Liverpool

This summer, Mohamed Salah was the subject of some massive interest from Saudi Arabia and an eye-watering offer. When that offer landed, I believed Liverpool should take it because it was the area of the pitch in which they had the most cover, because of Salah’s age and because it was a huge amount of money. The other factor was that I couldn’t see Liverpool winning the title and they weren’t in the Champions League, so this made sense as a transition season while they bedded in their new midfielders.

Yeah, I might have got that badly wrong (no, not “as usual”). It is certainly true the offer was massive, but then that might still be on the table next year just so long as Saudi Arabia haven’t given up on the need to buy expensive footballers now they have won the rights to host the World Cup.

More importantly, Liverpool may yet be in a title challenge because this season is becoming impossible to work out. Just when you think you have seen a team’s strengths, they flip over to show you the weakness. Liverpool certainly have their own, but the home form is relentless and that might just be enough if Manchester City stutter.

Salah is flying. On Sunday he reached 200 goals in English football. After failing to assist or score in his previous three club games, the brace against Brentford made it 14 goals and assists in the league alone. The only person with more than that is Erl… OK, obviously you know who it is.
Arsenal

We have to conclude that Gabriel Jesus cannot be relied upon to start more than 25 league games a season. The striker is wanted by the Brazilian football federation this week, who it seems aren’t convinced by Arsenal’s prognosis, but Mikel Arteta has said that the latest injury is a huge worry and Jesus is not expected to play until December. He has played 363 minutes in the Premier league this season.

As alternatives, Arteta has started Eddie Nketiah as the central striker and seen him score a hattrick. He has started Kai Havertz there in the Community Shield and seen him do about as much as he has in central midfield. He started Leandro Trossard as both a false nine and a more conventional centre forward.
Related Article
Arsenal have one major advantage over Spurs that makes them true title contenders

Nketiah probably wouldn’t agree, but you wonder whether Trossard might just be the answer moving forward. His creativity, tendency to drift left (and allow Gabriel Martinelli to move centrally) and set-piece delivery are all useful to Arsenal. Trossard, naturally a left winger, is able to drag defenders out of position that could be crucial against a deep-lying defence. Against Burnley, he was able to repeatedly find space around the penalty area and scored when finding space inside it.
Interestingly, Arteta spoke last season after a win at Leicester about how the switching of positions with Martinelli can increase Arsenal’s creativity:

“He [Trossard] is so good in the small spaces. He’s got that creativity to open people up and I’m really happy with him. We have the option to play Leo as the No 9 and we have the option to play Gabi as the No 9 and Leo on the left.”

The theory is this: if Nketiah plays and is presented with chances, that system works fine. But if Nketiah is starved of the ball, Arsenal can become a little formulaic and opponents can double up on Martinelli and Bukayo Saka, particularly if Havertz isn’t a threat from midfield. In those scenarios, you’d be better having the flexible forward.
Tottenham

Ah well, it was fun while it lasted. All season, sensible Tottenham supporters have been telling everybody around them who would listen that this squad might be too thin to sustain a top-four push, let alone a title challenge. But even those emphatic realists didn’t expect all of those problems to afflict Tottenham in the space of 90 minutes.

James Maddison will be out for a while, after his ankle injury is worse than Tottenham medics first feared. Cristian Romero is out for another two matches. Micky van de Ven has a hamstring injury that left him barely able to walk from the pitch. They were already dealing with the haunting fear caused by the departure of Pape Matar Sarr and Yves Bissouma to the Africa Cup of Nations in January and Son Heung-min to the Asian Cup at the same time.
Related Article
Postecoglou's mad tactics have put the fun back into Spurs - no wonder fans applaud a defeat

Ange Postecoglou spoke about “running out of steam” at Molineux on Saturday, and he’s probably right. But this was also an indication of the problem faced by every manager with a defined playing style that demands complete buy-in from the players. When you then bring in fringe players who haven’t played much competitive action in your system, they can struggle to replicate it.

And so to the last 10 minutes. Tottenham had already sat deeper than Postecoglou would like, trying to hold onto a lead rather than playing their own way regardless of the scoreline (as we saw so emphatically on Monday night). The manager said as much: “We started well but we could have been a little bit more positive, a little bit more aggressive, particularly with the ball.”

Instead, the changes to the team, particularly in defence, made those players implement risk-averse football which, counterintuitively, becomes more risky when it goes against the manager’s own preferred style. Suddenly you’ve got Eric Dier launching the ball out for throw-ins rather than trying to keep possession and Wolves ramping up pressure that the makeshift defence was then unable to repel.

This doesn’t all have to be the end, obviously. The next two fixtures – Aston Villa and Manchester City – are unhelpfully tricky, given Romero and Van de Ven will both likely be missing for both. But more important is that those who were getting carried away – inside and outside Tottenham’s support – temper their expectations a touch. Qualifying for the Champions League was always the high-end achievement of this first Spurs season under a new regime. If Maddison and Van de Ven are out for a significant period of time, January is going to make that very difficult indeed.
Aston Villa

Another week and another home win, because that is all Aston Villa apparently do at Villa Park now. This makes it 13 home league wins on the spin. Even more ridiculous is that Unai Emery’s team have now scored three or more goals in each of their last six home games in the Premier League.
Related Article
'Detail is key': Five ways Emery has transformed Aston Villa after the dark days of Gerrard

There were two noticeable features of the win over Fulham that deserve mention. The first is simple: Emery chose not to make a high number of changes, a different strategy to other managers around him. Matty Cash, Douglas Luiz and Pau Torres were the players to return. Villa took a commanding early lead and then played lower-energy football to preserve their reserves. That is an effective way to get through post-European assignments, particularly at home. Brighton, take note.

It was one of those returnees who impressed most. Villa paid £33m for Pau Torres in the summer, seen by some as a risky signing given the question marks over whether he would suit the Premier League and Villa’s multiple options in the position. Then Tyrone Mings got a serious injury and Torres stepped up to be the leader of the defence.

Torres is such a useful player for Emery’s system because he is capable of conducting the speed of play in possession. Often he plays the short, sideways passing we expect from so many teams. But his passing range, switching up to either arrow a long ball out to a wide forward or through the lines to an advanced midfielder, just makes Villa tick. He is a supreme passer of the ball and he’s doing it from centre-back. That is what Emery craves most.
Man Utd

Something extraordinary happened this week. At Wembley Stadium, Gareth Southgate announced his England squad for two forthcoming European Championship qualifiers. He included Harry Maguire and… there wasn’t a widespread guffawing. Wonders will never cease.

After all of the setbacks – the decline in club form, the ostracism from the first team, the mockery of supposed friends and foes because it really is funny to victimise a player until he reveals his mental struggle and then the same people tweet #BeKind – Maguire has, somehow, come back as strong.

Erik ten Hag tried to avoid it for as long as possible, but Maguire is back in the team and back performing. He was arguably United’s best player against Sheffield United, was definitely their best player against Fulham and the highest performer again against Luton on Saturday. Between all that, he scored the winner against FC Copenhagen and was again arguably Man of the Match.

This is no joke. It is not easy to come into any team having been left out in the cold – least of all when that team is struggling in front of a new goalkeeper and with injuries mounting up. Maguire’s start against Brentford on October 7 was his seventh in the league since August 2022. Add in the pressure upon him given the derision and mockery he had previously faced, and you have a bloke who deserves enormous respect for his strength of character.
Newcastle

The energy is running out and the impact of last season’s impressive Champions League qualification is becoming increasingly apparent. The danger is that Newcastle lose out both ways. They are bottom of their Champions League group and are favourites to stay there ahead of a trip to Paris that could eliminate them from the knockout stages.
Related Article
Newcastle may be forced to rip up January transfer strategy as injury crisis bites

Eddie Howe’s team have played four games on the weekends after their Champions League fixtures and have dropped points in three of them. At Wolves, they were lucky to escape with a point. At West Ham the same, albeit with their opponents looking equally blunted by midweek commitments. At Bournemouth on Saturday, Newcastle lost 2-0 and Nick Pope was their best player.

It isn’t just the fatigue in those who do play. The rapid increase in midweek matches and subsequent lack of recovery time has clearly played a role in Newcastle’s injury crisis. They were without nine players at Bournemouth, Miguel Almiron went off injured and they have no fit strikers. It’s a point we’ve raised before, but having all those full-backs and relying upon Callum Wilson’s fitness over a 50-game season was simply too risky.

“We couldn’t be where we needed to be for it,” said Eddie Howe after the game. “In and out of possession we were unrecognisable. They’re such honest players and they’ve given me so much that I’m absolutely clear I have to support them.”

Howe is clearly right, if a little resigned. You can’t simply magic energy back into your squad by repeatedly listening to Jake Humphrey’s “High Performance Podcast”. The only answer is for Newcastle to cope or, as is more likely, fall into the Europa League or worse and focus on the Premier League.

More interesting is how this season is playing out amongst an element of the club’s supporters. Changes to the club’s ticketing system means that there are newer faces in the away end this year, and Newcastle have only won one of their six away league games. At full-time on Saturday evening, Kieran Trippier argued with one supporter who was clearly giving the team grief. That simply wouldn’t have happened last season because everybody was supporting everybody else. It’s worth keeping an eye on any foolish entitlement growing.
Brighton

Like Newcastle one place above them, Brighton have an injury crisis likely caused by the addition of midweek European games into their usual schedule. For Sunday’s visit of Sheffield United, the list of absentees was as follows: Lewis Dunk, Pervis Estupinan, Tariq Lamptey, Solly March, James Milner, Danny Welbeck, Julio Enciso. To which we can add Evan Ferguson, omitted from the matchday squad at late notice after picking up an injury. Brighton’s squad is thinner than Newcastle’s, albeit the versatility of certain players helps to hide it.
Related Article
'I don't like 80% of English referees': Brighton's De Zerbi lashes out after Sheff Utd draw

Even so, Roberto De Zerbi still got it wrong against Sheffield United. Leaving Kaoru Mitoma on the bench was vaguely understandable, but it left a front three of Facundo Buonanotte (18), Simon Adingra and Ansu Fati (both 21 and in their first seasons in England). If that sounds like an attacking unit that might be a little raw, so it proved.

A manager cannot legislate for silly mistakes such as Mahmoud Dahoud getting himself sent off for a brainless tackle. But the question is how Brighton’s stability is being affected by the constant changes in team selection that De Zerbi feels that he needs to make. There were another six changes from Thursday to Sunday, but even that doesn’t demonstrate the full change: Pascal Gross to right-back, a new goalkeeper, a new central defender, a new left-back, two new midfielders and that raw front three.

You see the impact of those changes most in defence. Brighton have played 12 league games this season and are still yet to keep a clean sheet. They were fortunate to avoid defeat against a Sheffield United side that is yet to pick up an away point this season. De Zerbi’s team have also not won a Premier League match since 24 September.
West Ham
Related Article
Arsenal should start wondering why they didn’t spend £30m on James Ward-Prowse

West Ham signing James Ward-Prowse was the most obvious transfer of the Premier League summer. West Ham had lost an influential central midfielder and so needed a new one with experience. West Ham had two big central defenders and a towering central midfielder. David Moyes enthuses about the importance of a set-piece threat.

Ward-Prowse had actually seemed more of a threat from open play in the early season, but worry no longer. When West Ham began to win corner after corner, and wide free-kick after wide-free-kick, you sensed what was coming. It took West Ham to go 2-1 down, but then came the peppering.

Ward-Prowse now has five league assists this season. West Ham have scored seven headed goals and had 40 headed shots, both of which place them No 1 in the division. Some things just make sense, and Ward-Prowse hanging crosses to the back post or under the goalkeeper’s eyes is one of them.
Chelsea
Related Article
Haaland’s genius cancelled out by late Palmer penalty as Chelsea hold Man City in thriller

Whether Cole Palmer left Manchester City purely because he wasn’t guaranteed game time or because his sale made sense from a FFP perspective (is there any more romantic phrase in football than “pure profit”?), he has taken to life at Chelsea just fine. Stamford Bridge has been a Bermuda Triangle for a series of younger signings over the last two years, but Palmer is now the first name on the Chelsea teamsheet.

You can argue that being given penalty duties is an easy way to inflate your statistics, and that would make you a fool. Palmer is 21 years old and in Chelsea’s last five matches he has been asked to take one penalty against Arsenal, one against Tottenham and another against his old club. He’s scored all three beautifully.

There is bags of talent on the ball and work off it, but more than anything else managers look for leadership qualities in young players, for their ability to produce their best work under intense pressure. That sums up Palmer perfectly. Chelsea have landed one here.
Brentford
This isn’t just about Thomas Frank, but this is the only obvious place to make this wider point. After the game, Frank railed against a VAR decision.

“My look is that first and foremost, on the pitch it was a clear foul and a yellow card. But in the old days, and I’m not that old but let’s say five years ago, it was never a red. A yellow probably on the pitch, but these days with the VAR and the way they are being reffed, then I think it’s a red.

“If you look at the slow motion footage that you use, then it’s clear studs on leg and he’s definitely going over the ball with too much force, Endo on Christian. And then you can look at the four bloody marks on his leg! With that in mind, I just want consistency.”

You could make the argument, I guess. It looked like both players were going in and neither used two feet, but you could potentially make a case for it – it was a subjective decision and the call was that it didn’t quite merit a red card. But Brentford were also 2-0 down at that point.

VAR is a circus at the moment. But part of the reason for that is because VAR dominates every post-match discussion in studios and in every post-match press conference. It creates a scandal where one need not exist.

And it’s exhausting. If what you/we/everyone wants is more correct decisions and a better culture around refereeing decisions, at some point we’re all going to have to grow up a bit. We’ve got journalists saying “hey I’m just asking questions here” about corruption. We’ve got managers like Roberto De Zerbi saying he “dislikes 80 per cent of English referees”. We’ve got constant mania around every call. How is any of this going to help?
Wolves

All hail the Gary O’Neil midtable party. Supporters would be more than happy to admit that there have been doubts along the way (and the defeat to Sheffield United was an unfortunate misstep), but Wolves are now scampering away from danger at a rate of knots.

Since they lost to Liverpool in mid-September, their fourth defeat in five league games to open the season, Wolves have taken 12 points from seven matches and lost only once. They are unbeaten in four at Molineux, which sounds far more impressive when you learn that their four opponents were Manchester City, Tottenham, Aston Villa and Tottenham.
Related Article
'Big dog behaviour': Inside Gary O'Neil's Wolves start and the moment that changed everything

Of all the possible indicators of a squad enjoying life under a manager, two jump out at Wolves. The first is the improvement in players whose form dipped badly last season (or barely even got off the ground). Jose Sa seems more confident. Rayan Ait-Nouri is useful again. Matheus Cunha looks more like the player they thought they were getting. Pablo Sarabia woke up in style on Saturday.

Secondly, look at the fight within this Wolves team. Liverpool and Arsenal are the only two Premier League teams (by the end of Saturday’s action) to have scored more goals after the 80th minute than O’Neil’s this season. They won at Everton in the 87th minute. They came down from a goal and a man down to draw at Luton. They scored an 88th-minute winner at Bournemouth. They scored twice in stoppage time against Tottenham, believing that they could win the game immediately after getting back into it.

Those goals alone account for more than half of Wolves’ points so far this campaign. Without them, they and O’Neil would be in trouble. With them comes proof of a decent manager who has found a group of willing workers and worries of relegation that now look utterly wasted.
Crystal Palace

Those leaving Selhurst Park on Saturday afternoon more than a little grumpy and underwhelmed (and Roy Hodgson was amongst them) has their minds full of an unpleasant question that may have a lingering impact: where has Crystal Palace’s home form gone?

The inability to win at home is, ultimately, what did for Patrick Vieira. He failed to win each of his last seven home league games as Palace scored only twice. That run did include four draws against decent opposition – Manchester United, Newcastle, Brighton, Liverpool – but the mood at Selhurst became a little too apathetic.

Hodgson changed all that. He won his first home game 2-1 against Leicester and then took eight points from his next four to close out the season. When Palace promptly beat Wolves 3-2 in early September to overshadow a narrow home defeat to Arsenal on the opening weekend, all seemed well. That was 14 points from seven home league games in total – you don’t get much better than that at bottom-half clubs.

Since then, that home form has declined badly. Palace have drawn against Fulham and Nottingham Forest, lost to Tottenham and then conceded three times at home to Everton on Saturday. They suddenly seem incapable of displaying any resolve against pressure. Tyrick Mitchell is off form; so too is Marc Guehi.

Hodgson admitted after the game that the Selhurst form was “very concerning” and he’s right. Palace are thankful that they have won away at Manchester United and Burnley in two of their last three away games otherwise they would be down in trouble. Luton and Bournemouth come immediately after the international break. This is not the time for things to fall apart.
Everton

Things we expected Sean Dyche to do at Everton: 1) Make them harder to beat away from home; 2) Make them defensively miserly at home; 3) Create a set-piece threat; 4) Get them to cross the ball repeatedly into the box.

In the early days, barely any of these were present. But gradually, Dyche is turning Everton into exactly what he wanted, a high-end version of his Burnley team but with extra attacking threat and midfield guile. There is fight in this team, demonstrated by twice being pegged back and twice pushing back to retake the lead.
Related Article
Everton's takeover takes crucial next step in latest sign club's fortunes are changing

There is also an unrivalled ability to score early goals. In their last three matches in all competitions alone, Everton have scored in the first, seventh and 13 minutes. They have scored more goals in the first 15 minutes of Premier League games than anyone else and also a higher proportion. Thirty-six per cent of Everton’s goals have come in the 15th minute or earlier. Is this evidence that opposition managers presume that a Dyche team will aim to work its way into a match and are being tricked?

Whatever the reason, it’s working for Dyche. Everton have taken 10 points from their last five league games and that includes the customary defeat at Anfield. The threat of a points deduction is the same, but its impact is being mitigated. And now Everton have won consecutive away league games for the first time since May 2021.

As for those expectations of Dyche, he’s showing off new tricks too. Everton have scored three or more goals in three of their last eight away league games. Before that, they hadn’t scored three or more in a Premier League away game in 44 attempts, a run stretching back to February 2021.
Nottingham Forest

Same old, same old. The win over Aston Villa last week was earned via a defensive masterclass, with Forest repelling set pieces and Villa pressure before capitalising on the counter attack. Here was the opposite: Forest conceded plenty of set pieces and then proved themselves incapable of holding on.

Forest’s ability to lose games having held a lead is unmatched in the Premier League. They have done so seven times since the start of last season, more than any other team. Part of the issue is what happens once Taiwo Awoniyi is substituted. The centre forward is coming back from injury and so was never likely to play 90 minutes, but that’s par for the course. Awoniyi has never played 90 minutes for Forest in any competition and has only passed 80 minutes three times.

Awoniyi is so good at holding up the ball that, when he leaves the pitch, Forest lose an outlet (sorry Chris Wood, this isn’t your thing at all). That allows the opposition to push further up the pitch and squeeze Forest’s defenders and midfielders, thus causing them to panic and either give the ball away or put it out of play.

That left the course of the game to be decided by the result of those set pieces. Forest left Jarrod Bowen free from four yards out and then Tomas Soucek, the biggest player on the pitch, free at the back post to score the winner. These are the sort of things that make defeat more frustrating and entirely merited.
Fulham
Related Article
The Fulham fans leading the fightback against football's exorbitant ticket prices

It’s difficult to criticise any team for losing at Villa Park these days, but Fulham potentially do have a problem. The signing of a new contract by Marco Silva was heralded as a sign of investment in their future, but Silva is struggling to stem the tide at the moment. Fulham have won two league matches since the opening day of the season: Luton Town at home, Sheffield United at home.

Before the game, a couple of Fulham’s players were asked whether the loss of Aleksandar Mitrovic was the deciding factor and all of them denied that to be the case. And they’re right: of course Fulham are missing Mitrovic’s presence (they have scored more than once in two league games this season), but they have also failed to keep a clean sheet in six games and are asking – and expecting – Joao Palhinha to do everything. I can promise you he will get sick of that with Bayern Munich sniffing.

To that we must add the discontentment of home supporters, who campaigned last week about the greed of their club in their ticket pricing system, and the lingering resentment over allowing Mitrovic to leave without having an adequate replacement lined up. As we head into the international break, the best Fulham fans can hope for is a slightly wasted season.
Bournemouth

Dominic Solanke is going through what we might call the Ollie Watkins Centre Forward Revival. The impact might not be as pronounced, but it might just make Bournemouth’s season worthwhile and it certainly helped Andoni Iraola beat Newcastle to cement his own position.

Last season, Solanke scored six goals in 33 Premier League matches. Despite Bournemouth struggling at the start of this season, Solanke has six goals in 12 matches. And that’s not just down to the quality of his finishing. In 2022-23, Solanke managed a total 9.1 xG in the league – he’s already up to 5.4 this season.

As with Watkins, this is all about being refined into a centre forward rather than an all-action one. Playing further up the pitch means that he is playing fewer passes and those passes are much shorter in length (last season he would drop deep and play crossfield balls). Solanke has provided one assist this season (seven last year) and that’s because he’s creating fewer chances.

And so to the statistics that really matter. Solanke is taking more shots than last year and those shots are, on average, significantly closer to goal – inevitably his shooting efficiency goes up. And although he’s having fewer touches of the ball than last season, he’s having a greater number in the opposition penalty area.
Luton Town

Rob Edwards is right that Luton have come a long way in three months. That he, his players and the away supporters were deeply disappointed to leave Old Trafford having lost by a single goal is enough evidence of that. Edwards’ claim that Luton had “almost as much of the ball” was only true for the second half, but they certainly didn’t lie down and had six (admittedly low-danger) shots.
Related Article
Luton fans shamed their club with Liverpool tragedy chants and should be punished

Edwards’ issue is not that his team is poor in attack and defence, at least compared with our preseason expectations. It is that Luton are losing tight matches through their inability to keep clean sheets. They have allowed an xG of at least 1 in all but one game this season (the 1-1 home draw against Wolves, who had 10 men for an hour). They have conceded a goal in every league game too.

The lack of a clean sheet need not be a problem. Brighton have also not kept one, but then they are scoring at a rate of 2.1 goals per game. Luton’s problem is that they are not getting full value for the positives within their performances because they are being punished for ceding one too many good chances.

If you have conceded one goal or fewer in six matches this season, one fewer than Tottenham and Newcastle, you should be higher up the league. But the attack isn’t quite bailing out the defence and the defence isn’t quite bailing out the attack. That might just become the story of the season.
Burnley

There are certain non-negotiables for every promoted team, and one of them is defending crosses and set-pieces into the box. It is typically an area of strength, purely because the Championship tends to breed defenders who are capable of headed clearances – there are typically more long balls and more crosses into the box. After promotion, you cede a little more possession and territory and therefore expect an onslaught. If you can be beaten by terrific movement, you must guard against being undone by the basics.

Burnley aren’t even doing that. They actually defended pretty well in front of their own penalty area on Saturday, but repeatedly conceded chances – and goals – from wide areas. For the first, a cross comes from wide and Burnley lose the first header in their penalty area and leave Leandro Trossard free for the second. The third goal comes from a corner, with a header hitting the crossbar before Oleksandr Zinchenko’s wonderful finish.

The second goal is the most alarming. When Trossard’s corner is delivered, William Saliba is beyond the back post. Not only is he allowed to run beyond Zeki Amdouni (who ends up berating his teammates, for some reason), but that run is not spotted by anyone else. Saliba ends up standing in front of goalkeeper James Trafford, on his own a yard away from goal. The corner is delivered perfectly and Trafford is helpless.

This isn’t good enough. An acclimatisation period is understandable and so are away defeats to high-quality opponents. But the least you expect is to be outclassed on occasion by brilliant skill, rather than undone by two or three simple lapses in concentration that turn a potential point into another defeat.
Sheffield United

Paul Heckingbottom wanted a little luck, and he has found some. In midweek, the independent VAR panel (a different rant, but: I have no idea what the point is of having people reviewing something that has already been decided three days after the incident and making those findings public) ruled that Sheffield United should not have been awarded their last-minute winning penalty against Wolves. This weekend, a Brighton player got himself sent off and gave Heckingbottom’s team the impetus.
Related Article
Sheffield United have chosen profit over fans with a season of record-breakingly bad football

All season, Heckingbottom has been asking his players to be braver in possession. He can accept things will go wrong, but he cannot accept players cowering in a proverbial corner when their team needs them, as in the 8-0 home defeat to Newcastle.

At the Amex, his players did that. They were attempting to push forward even before the red card, after the manager had instructed his players to stop playing back to the goalkeeper for Wes Foderingham to hit the ball long and lose possession. With a man advantage, Sheffield United found those spaces, played progressive passes and were unfortunate not to win consecutive Premier League games.

Who knows if any of this is sustainable, but Heckingbottom et al face Bournemouth (home) and Burnley (away) after the international break. The headline news is that the manager will make it through the break with his job intact. Those games offer a chance to improve after a wretched start to the season.
